title: andrew made royals family everyone
story: Andrew has made royals the family everyone on the estate signs petition to get evictedIf the Royal Family lived on a normal street, neighbours would whisper they were at it again last night, shooting partridges until two in the morning, argues Mirror columnist Mark SteelMark Steel likened the crises engulfing the royals to something from the Jeremy Kyle show Image: Getty ImagesopinionByMark Steel:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan Many people suggest they love the royals, because at heart they’re just an ordinary family. So we should be grateful to the extra effort Prince Andrew has put in to make them seem not just ordinary, but like the family on the housing estate everybody signs a petition to get evicted. If they’d been on the Jeremy Kyle show, their title along the bottom would have gone on for  minutes, starting: “One son involved with gang that was put in jail… another son married teenager while having affair with woman he eventually married after first one crashed in car… grandkids cut off after fleeing to Canada and calling family racist on TV…” If they did live in a normal street, all the neighbours would whisper to each other: “They were at it again last night, keeping us awake by shooting partridges until two in the morning.” Now Andrew’s case for ending civil proceedings in which he’s accused of sex offences is that the accuser once received money in a “non-disclosure deal”, to keep quiet about similar goings-on from the man thought to have been arranging them. This seems an unusual line to take, to say: “I didn’t do it. And it’s not fair because she promised she wouldn’t mention it.” The Mirroraposs newsletter brings you the latest news, exciting showbiz and TV stories, sport updates and essential political information.The newsletter is emailed out first thing every morning, at noon and every evening. Never miss a moment by signing up to our newsletter here.  But I’m sure Andrew knows what he’s doing. I might try something similar next time I get a fine for driving in a bus lane. It’s probably all part of his selfless campaign to modernise his family, by making them seem like they’re from a typical troubled background. I expect the next story will be that Andrew has been training the corgis for dog-fighting in the grounds of Balmoral. He’ll invite his mates over and they’ll stand in the woods betting, and shouting: “GO on Digger, use your teeth son.” Then he’ll be exposed selling iPads that he robbed from PC World, after he was caught because CCTV showed him using a Range Rover as his getaway car. And the security guard identied him because Andrew demanded he stood up and saluted him even though he was tied to a chair. But his defence team will argue the case should be thrown out because the store once signed a non-disclosure deal with Crazy Ernie, who’s doing  years for blowing up the Bank of England with gunpowder. But he’ll clear it all up in an interview on Newsnight, in which he explains he only went round the pubs of Windsor selling the iPads, because he needed to explain to the bar staff that he wasn’t going to buy their crisps any more. The Queen has reportedly been paying his legal fees, but she needs to go further to complete the image. She has to arrive at the court screaming: “He’s f***ing innocent you ****”, while William yells “What you f***ing looking at  Do you want some, do you ” to the judge, for asking him to put out his cigarette and turn off his motorbike in the courtroom. They’re worth every penny. news uk-news cctv-shows-moment-teenager-lured-"Moment teen is attacked while thinking he was meeting girl for dateByHollie BoneNews ReporterBeth Cruse:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsThis is the terrying moment a teenager who thought he was meeting a girl for a date was instead stabbed in a vicious revenge attack. The -year-old boy was stabbed in February last year after he was lured out by Snapchat message he thought were from a girl wanting to meet up, Bristol Live reports. But when he arrived at the meeting point in Fishponds, Bristol, he was kned nine times and left for dead by two  year olds in what is described as a revenge attack.The two teenagers, who have since turned  and cannot be named because of their age, were sentenced to youth custody in Bristol Crown Court on Friday.A -year-old male, who stabbed the victim, pleaded guilty to causing grievous bodily harm ahead of a trial in November, while a female was found guilty of the same offence by jurors, BristolLive reported.During her trial, the jury were told the victim was part of a rival group within Bristol and was deliberately lured to the Ridgeway Road area that night so he could be attacked. The male received a four-year sentence and the female three years.  Judge Michael Longman described the attack as co-ordinated and done with the intention of causing very serious injuries. Detective Inspector Roger Doxsey said: “This was a vicious and calculated attack on a then -year-old boy. He was mercilessly chased and stabbed approximately nine times and left for dead. “Described in court as a ‘Snapchat honey trap’, the female lured the victim to a park in Fishponds on the understanding that they were having a date, whereupon he was set upon by a number of males with knives.  “After the attack the male offender sent a ‘mic drop emoji’ with his face on via Snapchat to the female offender. His emoji meant ‘job done’ and shows the true intent behind the crime. “The victim was in intensive care but has thankfully made a steady recovery from his multiple injuries. He bravely gave evidence and we are grateful for his and his family’s support.”Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON CCTVCCTV footageCourt caseCrown courtCrimeTeenagersKne crime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. news uk-news covid-become-very-similar-common-"Covid: One in  estimated to have had virus in last weekBySam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A leading doctor believes coronavirus will soon resemble a common cold and thinks Omicron could be the beginning of the end of the pandemic. The University of Warwickaposs Dr Mike Tildesley believes the world will soon learn toagain as normal. The medic, a member of the Scientic Pandemic Influenza Modelling group which feeds into SAGE, previously questioned the need for curbs.He raised hopes that cases are starting to slow in Covid hot-spot London despite the UK reporting nearly , new cases on Friday.Dr Tildesley pointed to the capitalaposs flatlining cases and hospital admissions as an encouraging sign that things are starting to turn around.  He told Times Radio: The thing that might happen in the future is you may see the emergence of a new iant that is less severe, and ultimately, in the long term, what happens is Covid becomes endemic and you have a less severe version. Itaposs very similar to the common cold that weaposve lived with for many years. Weaposre not quite there yet but possibly Omicron is the first ray of light there that suggests that may happen in the longer term - it is, of course, much more transmissible than Delta was, which is concerning, but much less severe. Hopefully, as we move more towards the spring and we see the back of Omicron, we can get more inter-relationship of living with Covid as an endemic disease and protecting the vulnerable.  But he did state that the North East and North West of England are seeing the most concerning rates of the Omicron iant. However, he added: It doesnapost sound all doom and gloom, what we are seeing from hospital admissions is that stays in hospital do appear to be on average shorter, which is good news, symptoms appear to be a little bit milder, so this what we are seeing consistently with the Omicron iant. His comments come after the Prime Minister told a Downing Street press conference this week that England had a chance to ride out this Omicron wave without shutting down our country.  On Friday, the UK reported , daily coronavirus cases and another  deaths. The government say there are , people in hospital with coronavirus as of the last count. Of those,  of whom are in ventilation beds. The R rate has increased and is now estimated to be between . and ., according to the latest figures. Just over  million people have now had a third vaccine, stats show. With so much changing so quickly, keep on top of what is happening with the Mirroraposs news updates by email. Delivered straight to your inbox, our daily coronavirus briefing will keep you informed of what is happening with Covid, lockdown, the vaccination rollout and the impact on how we live.here.However, health secretary Sajid Javid says the NHS is facing a rocky few weeks ahead as it contends with a wave of Omicron cases.He said: The best thing people can do is get their booster jab. We know now that Omicron is less severe… and we certainly know that once you get boosted that your chance of hospitalisation, our latest analysis shows, is almost % less than it was with Delta. title: designer clothes exist only online
story: Exclusive: Designer clothes that exist only online being sold for thousands in mind-boggling trendDolce and Gabbana, Nike and Adidas are among brands designing clothes for the virtual world with each piece being sold as a Non-Fungible Tokenbut critics say the prices are out of proportionPeople are splashing out thousands on virtual designer gearByJack Clover:,  Jan  but critics say the prices are out of proportion" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _SOCIAL-Virtual-designer-clothes.jpg" data-tracking"facebook|share|top" but critics say the prices are out of proportion" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _SOCIAL-Virtual-designer-clothes.jpg" data-tracking"twitter|share|top" but critics say the prices are out of proportion" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _SOCIAL-Virtual-designer-clothes.jpg" data-tracking"whatsapp|share|top"| commentsFashion fans are forking out thousands on pounds… for clothes that only exist online. The digital togs can be used to dress cartoon versions of participants in virtual worlds. A £, golf outfit is just one of the items available online, and a matching Tam O’Shanter hat will set you back another £,. For £,, you can also get a tracksuit covered in the Decentraland Games logo, which can be worn in Decentraland – one of the most developed virtual worlds on the internet. Designer brands are also getting in on the mindboggling new trend, with Dolce  Gabbana, Nike and Adidas all producing clobber for the virtual world. Each piece of clothing is sold as an NFT – or non-fungible token – which can be bought and sold in real-le like a painting or any other valuable item. scoops@sundaymirror Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter  An industry source said: “Fashion in the real world might seem mad at times with some of the outfits that go for silly money, but this is a whole new realm. “We are talking about people paying thousands for something that only exists as pixels on a screen. It is unbelievable.” So far, DG has auctioned off nine digital designer pieces for an eye-watering total of £.million. The lots included The Glass Suit – a green and silver outfit which sold for £,, alongside a real-le version of the suit. In March, the first virtual fashion week will be held – in the real world. And virtual sportswear is set to be big business too.  Nike has bought tech company RTFKT, recently valued at £million, to help them create and sell virtual trainers. And Adidas has teamed up with two companies to take their Originals range into cyberspace. Tech consultant Grace Rachmany said: “Selling clothing in games is here to stay but I think the prices are out of proportion right now.  “A lot of people have money in cryptocurrencies that they won’t take out because they’ll have to pay tax so to them, it’s like play money.”The surge of interest in NFTs comes after Facebook founder Mark Zuckerberg announced the future of his company lay in the “metaverse” – a virtual D world.There, users can play games, shop, interact with friends and even hold business meetings wearing virtual reality goggles,they wish.  Decentraland, which has its own cryptocurrency, recently made headlines when a plot of “real estate” sold for £.million. But real-le criminals are cashing in too. Todd Kramer, of New York’s Ross + Kramer Gallery, spent £.million on NFT cartoon apes from Bored Ape Yacht Club, only for them to be stolen by a hacker.A-Z on digital NFTsNon-fungible tokens, or NFTs, are one of the world’s biggest internet crazes. While some experts say they are the future of the art and fashion world, others believe investors will suffer a similar fate to those who splashed out during the dot-com boom  years ago – only to lose heavily. An NFT is a unique unit of computer data stored in a special piece of code called a blockchain. It can be associated with a digital asset such as a video, picture, quote or even an outfit. The fact they have a unique signature means they are finite and can be bought and sold like real-world artwork or collectibles. A blockchain allows cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin to exist as it records on a digital ledger proof that a token changed hands. While for cryptocurrencies each token has the same value like a £ coin, NFTs all have dferent values depending on how much people are willing to spend on them – like paintings or antiques. The first known NFT was a digital graphic called Quantum designed in  by artist Kevin McCoy and we Jenner. He sold the artwork to entrepreneur Anil Dash during a presentation for just £. but it is now thought to be worth more than £million. The niche technology only became mainstream in  with a string of highprofile sales. Artist Mike Winkelmann, known as Beeple, sold his work Everydays: the First  Days for .million in a sale that shook the art world. Since then major artists such as David Hockney and Jeff Koons, and singer Grimes, have sold NFTs for vast sums. title: ex army chief backs calls
story: Ex-Army chief backs our calls to honour tragic hero soldier who served with Prince HarryThe parents of soldier Nathan Hunt want him added to the national Armed Forces Memorial but Ministry of Defence refuses – claiming his suicide was not linked to his servicePrince Harry served in Afghanistan with Nathan Image: EMPICS EntertainmentBySean Rayment:,  Jan | commentsThe family campaigning for a proper ­honour for tragic soldier Nathan Hunt are ­being backed by the Army’s former head. Nathan’s parents want to add his name to the national Armed Forces Memorial in Staffordshire.But the Ministry of Defence refuses – claiming his suicide and PTSD were not linked to his service. Lord Dannatt has now told the Sunday People he was “saddened” by the family’s treatment and pledged to raise the issue in the House of Lords.He said: “The first issue is to get the MoD to issue a clear policy and second to consider Nathan Hunt’s case fairly – and hopefully, favourably.”Royal Engineers warrant officer Nathan served alongside Prince Harry in Afghanistan in . Nathan received a Mention in Despatches for finding dozens of Taliban bombs and helped save many lives. His  years’ Army service included tours of Iraq, Bosnia and Northern Ireland. He was found hanged at his Lincoln home aged  on January , . That year Lord Dannatt introduced Nathan’s parents to Prince Harry and Meghan.  Last month Derek, , and Maria, , wrote to Harry asking for his support. As we reported, the prince wrote a moving reply saying he would always remember Nathan as a hero but was unable to help after losing his Army titles.  Derek said: “I’m delighted General Dannatt has agreed to help us. It seems he also feels that the MoD’s decision is unfair.” An ex-soldier himself, Derek claimed documents used by defence chiefs in the case contained errors. He said: “The MoD are more interested in protecting their reputation than trying to find out why Nathan took his own le. I also think they are trying to trash his reputation by saying that Nathan suffered from alcohol abuse and that he was aggressive. “Those comments refer to his first marriage which ended in . He was never violent to his we but the marriage was in trouble and like a lot of young men he thought the best way to deal with it was through drink. But to mention it in documents which were used to decide whether he should have his name added to the memorial seems very wrong.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Prince HarryTalibanBritish ArmyNHSHouse of LordsMinistry of DefenceRoyal FamilySoldiersArmed forcesPolitics" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: family 13 rented 8 bed
story: Family-of- in rented -bed house fear being homeless as council plans to evict themClford Westfall and Clair Pattersons family is now living in fear that they could be torn apart, after Bradford Council told them they must leave their home of two-and-a-half yearsClford Westfall and Clair Patterson live with their nine children, as well as Clair’s brother and Clford’s brother Image: Huddersfield ExaminerByKristian Johnson:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsA family-of- living in a huge eight-bedroom house are worried they may be left homeless after being handed an eviction notice from their local council. Clford Westfall and Clair Patterson live in Bradford, Yorkshire, with their nine children, as well as Clair’s brother and Clford’s brother, both of whom need extra support. But the family is now living in fear that they could be torn apart, after Bradford Council told them they must leave their home of two-and-a-half years by January . They even fear they could be forced to move into a hostel,they are unable to find another property by the deadline. Clford, , told Yorkshire Live that all they wanted was to be together as a family. The couple pay £, a month for the privately-rented property in Green Head Road and are desperate to remain in the area.Do you think the council should help this family  Share your view in the comments section below Their seven youngest children all go to school in Keighley and the family business, a toy shop in the town centre, is just a mile away. Clair said: If we lived where, it would be physically impossible for me to get seven kids to four dferent schools and then get to work. It just wouldnapost happen.” However, an extension to the property, built by the landlord, breaches planning regulations. The works exceeded the agreed dimensions and the house is now deemed too tall. Three separate retrospective planning applications and an appeal to the governmentaposs planning inspector have all failed. It led to the council obtaining a compulsory purchase order on the property. Clford, Clair and their family were initially told to move out by January . After Clford and Clair were told to leave, they said they asked for help from the council to find somewhere  to live after struggling to find anywhere suitable. There is nothing on the market for a family of our size, said Clford. We used to live in a three-bedroom house a few years ago. We were so happy, even though it was so small, but it just wasn’t big enough.  Since we have been in this big house, we have never been secure or comfortable. The council say they can’t put us in a four or five-bedroom house, because it would be overcrowded, but we need to be together. The couple say they have even asked whether they could have two homes knocked through into one. We’re not trying to be money-grabbers, said Clford. We’re completely willing to pay our way. We pay £, a month in rent. We pay £ a month council tax, we pay all the bills on our house. We don’t want a big house and for it to be cheap. We will pay. We just want to be together. Shortly after YorkshireLive approached Bradford Council for a comment, the local authority said it was trying to extend the deadline beyond January , but this is yet to be formally approved. A spokesperson added the council will continue to support the family throughout the process and that it is exploring the possibility of providing two accommodation units adjacent or in close proximity to each other. But Clford and Clair claim they have been told their family could be moved into a hostel. When they said that, I thought: ‘Is that for real ’ said Clford. “What’s one foot or two feet compared to making a family homeless  If we had to [leave Keighley] we’d do it. But a hostel  It just can’t happen. It wouldn’t work. The couple have one child together, but have custody for their eight children from previous relationships. The youngest is just two-years-old, while the oldest is . Local councillor Mohsin Hussain has tried to push the council to provide more help for the family. It is very dficult to find another property of this size, but I have said to the council that we need to find another property for Clford and his family to move into - or to extend the deadline,” he said. The council is not in the wrong on this, but there needs to be support from the council and from the housing associations for Clford and his family.” However, the family, who spent Christmas with the deadline looming large over their heads, are still no closer to finding somewhere  to live. The couple claim they pay their rent to Jigsaw Property Services. However, a spokesperson for the letting agent said they didn’t let the property out anymore. In a statement, a spokesperson for Bradford Council said: The breach that Mr Westfall appears to be referring to relates to planning permission rather than building regulations. This was obtained by the owner of the property in  to extend the house however, the actual works carried out went beyond that approved resulting in an unauthorised increase in the overall height of the property. Three separate retrospective planning applications for an increase in the roof height have been submitted since the works were undertaken. These applications were all refused and an appeal to the governmentaposs planning inspector by the owner challenging the decision was dismissed on May , . In view of this and as the owner failed to recty the breach, an enforcement notice was issued requiring them to carry out the work in accordance with the approved planning permission or demolish the unauthorised works. No appeal was submitted against the enforcement notice and therefore it should have been complied with by August , . With regard to rehousing Mr Westfall and his family, Mr Westfall and his family have been assessed by the Local Authority’s Housing Options Service in accordance with the Homelessness Reduction Act . The Housing Options Officer is currently exploring suitable rehousing options in the private and social housing sectors. This also includes providing two accommodation units adjacent or in close proximity to each other. Should Mr Westfall become homeless before the eviction deadline, the Local Authority will have a statutory duty to offer temporary accommodation with one of our commissioned providers. The temporary accommodation offer,needed, will be in the same location. The Local Authority will continue to support Mr Westfall and his family during this rehousing process. The council is currently in the process of preparing legal documentation to extend the current deadline of January ,  to allow additional time to source suitable housing options for Mr Westfall and his family. He will be in receipt of this documentation within the next seven days. title: family horrible mouldy flat so
story: Family-of- forced to wear coats in freezing council flat infested with black mouldEmma Reynolds, , and her kids, aged eight and three, have been housed in an "unfit" flat in Kings Norton, Birmingham, by Birmingham City Council, which is due to be demolishedEmma Reynolds and son Lewis are desperate to move Image: BPM MEDIAByStephanie BallooRyan MerrieldReporter:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsA mum and her two kids have to live in their coats after being housed in a freezing cold and damp council flat, she claims. Emma Reynolds, son Lewis, three, and daughter Leah, eight, spend day and night wrapped up in extra layers in the unfit property in Kings Norton, Birmingham. The -year-old mum claims she wakes every morning to a big puddle on her bedroom floor from the dripping window.The family have had to throw out toys, as well replace the sofa and other furniture and units, as well as pull up carpet and pull down wallpaper due to mould, reports Birmingham Live.Are you living in an aposunfitapos council property  Let us know at webnews@mirror She claims the conditions have worsened her sonaposs airway disease and exacerbated her bone condition. Emma said: I started having problems about a month after I moved in. I first noticed black mould in the bedroom and literally water all on the floor. I thought there was a leak or something so I just mopped it up and I left it. Then the next day, it came back again.  Every morning thereaposs a big puddle in my bedroom. Itaposs coming from the windows, itaposs dripping down from the windows. The family moved in eight months ago and in December, Emma had to pay over £ to top up the electricity, she says. We have to wear our coats and dressing gowns because itaposs that cold in here. Weaposve got storage heaters, but theyaposre not that hot so itaposs freezing in here.  When I do have them on itaposs taking a lot of electric, like Iaposve put £ on two days ago and Iaposve got £. Itaposs still freezing because of the damp. Itaposs costing a lot...weaposre constantly topping up on electric. Birmingham City Council is due to demolish the building in the near future and some flats have already been vacated in preparation.  Emma says sheaposs emailed and called the council but has so far not been moved. My son has got airways disease and since weaposve been here Iaposm constantly at the doctoraposs because his chest is getting worse and heaposs had to go on steroids, she continued. I suffer with depression as it is and Iaposm worried about my childrenaposs health over it.  I have a bone condition and some days, I canapost walk properly. I have pains in my legs and arms, and the damp is making it worse. Iaposm getting into bed of a night and Iaposm in agony. Birmingham City Council has apologised for the issues and vowed to treat the mould.In a statement, it said: We are sorry for the problems this tenant has experienced with mould in their flat. The block is due to be demolished in the next couple of years. In the meantime, we have organised for a contractor to treat the mould and will work with the tenant to rehouse them in line with our allocation policy. title: free lateral flow tests to
story: Free lateral flow tests to be scrapped as UK learns to live with Covid for new planUnder plans reportedly being weighed up by officials, the tests could soon only be available in "high-risk" settings such as care homes, hospitals and schools despite the rampant spread of the Omicron iant which only causes mild symptomsFree lateral flow tests could be scrapped in coming weeks, it is claimed Image: Getty Images iStockphotoByDave BurkeSenior News Reporter:,  Jan | commentsFree lateral flow tests could soon be scrapped for most of the public within weeks, reports claim. Under plans reportedly being weighed up by officials, the tests could soon only be available in high-risk settings such as care homes, hospitals and schools. Boris Johnson is said to be poised to announce the move as part of the Governmentaposs strategy for living with the virus. The move would also see the NHS Test and Trace service scaled back, according to The Sunday Times.A Whitehall source told the newspaper: “I don’t think we are in a world where we can continue to hand out free lateral flow tests to everybody forevermore. It’s likely we will move to a scenario where there is less testing but where we have a capacity to ramp it upnecessary, such as in the winter.” The Mirror has contacted the Department of Health for comment.The claim comes days after the PM announced that from next week people who test positive on a lateral flow test will no longer be required to confirm their condition with a PCR testthey have no symptoms.After the rule change on Tuesday, people who test positive with no symptoms - said to account for around % of people with Covid - will no longer need this follow-up PCR test.They will still have to isolate for at least seven days, but only from the date of their positive lateral flow test.A decision to scrap free lateral flow tests would happen at a time when Covid cases reach record levels, with nearly . million confirmed infections in the past week across the UK.  The Office for National Statisticsestimates that one in  people had the virus in the final week of  in England - with Wales and Scotland not far behind with one in  and Northern Ireland with one in . Although the number of people being treated in hospital with Covid has risen to its highest level in months - the number requiring ventilation is at its lowest since October last year. Scientists say increasing evidence shows that the Omicron iant causes less severe illness. Dr Mike Tildesley, a member of the Scientic Pandemic Influenza Modelling group, told Times Radio: “The thing that might happen in the future is you may see the emergence of a new iant that is less severe, and ultimately, in the long term, what happens is Covid becomes endemic and you have a less severe version. It’s very similar to the common cold that we’ve lived with for many years. “We’re not quite there yet but possibly Omicron is the first ray of light there that suggests that may happen in the longer term. It is, of course, much more transmissible than Delta was, which is concerning, but much less severe.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON NHSBoris JohnsonNursing homesPoliticsCoronavirus" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: habitual drinking sugary drinks can
story: Common diet habit can double risk of bowel cancer, new -year study suggestsNew research suggests that drinking sugar-sweetened drinks can double the risk of developing bowel cancer, which is the second biggest cancer killer and fourth most common cancer in the UKA new study has found that sugary rinks could contribute to bowel cancer cases Image: Getty Images Science Photo Library RFByDanny RiggJames RodgerRegional Content Editor:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsDrinking sugar-sweetened drinks can double the risk of bowel cancer, a new study suggests.Research published in the Gut journal found a higher risk of this cancer in people with a common habit also linked to obesity and type  diabetes.Bowel cancer is the second biggest cancer killer and the fourth most common cancer in the UK, affecting one in  men and one in  women in their letimes.More than % of the , people diagnosed with bowel cancer every year are over the age of , but it can affect people of any age.The study, which analysed almost , women over  years, suggests that the consumption of sugar-sweetened drinks raises the risk of developing the condition, BirminghamLive reports. Soft drink consumption has fallen in the UK in recent years, but an average of . litres per person were consumed last year, according to Statista. Thataposs most of a can of Coke per person every day.Women who drank two servings a day were twice as likely to be diagnosed with bowel cancer as the women who had only one a week, the study found.Researchers analysed the participantsapos lestyle, diet and family history of cancer.They found that all of the  women who developed bowel cancer before the age of  had a higher intake of sugar-sweetened drinks.Each daily serving is associated with a % higher risk, according to the studyaposs findings. This rises to % per daily serving during the teenage years. The study said: Reducing intake and or [substitution] with other healthier beverages among adolescents and young adults may serve as a potential actionable strategy to alleviate the growing burden of bowel cancer before the age of .Swapping out the sugary drinks for things like coffee or semi-skimmed and whole milk reduced the risk of getting bowel cancer.Nearly everyone survives this treatable and curable diseaseit is caught early, but more than , people die from it every year in the UK, according to Bowel Cancer UK. Also called colorectal cancer, bowel cancer causes bleeding from rectum, blood in stool, and pain or a lump in the back passage or abdomen, as well as tiredness and breathlessness.The cancer sometimes blocks the bowel, causing bloating, cramping pains in the abdomen, constipation and being unable to pass wind, and vomiting. You should visit AE immediatelyyour bowel is obstructed. news uk-news inside-worst-kfc-uk-locals-"KFC dubbed worst in the UK reviewed by CheshireLiveopinionByJonathan Blackburn:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsNo one at that place cares, it needs closing down. Worst KFC in the UK. I will not be ing to this KFC and I advise you never go. What an utter waste of money. We will have to be starving before we go back there again. Price gone up. Quality gone down...Whatever happened to the good old KFC  Basically: the chicken is always the driest thing on the planet. The KFC in Northwich, Cheshire, is not the most popular fast food outlet in the world, in fact, many people who go there advise others to stay well clear. The above complaints, taken from the last five reviews on Tripadvisor, donapost paint it in a particularly good light.Do you know of a worse fast food outlet than the Northwich KFC  Let us know at webnews@mirror It is rated on the site at just . stars out of five, with  of its  reviews scoring it as terrible - but how bad can it be  Cheshire Live reporter Jonathan Blackburn decided to see for himself.Itaposs KFC, after all, he writes. The ubiquitous grease-mongers, serving fried chicken by the bucket load from here to Tokyo, where the KFC aposBargain Bucketapos has become something of a Christmas Day tradition.  And yet, horror stories abound about this particular Cheshire eatery. The Northwich branch is infamous, I am told, and inspires eloquence and poetic patter from those who review it, arising in phrases such as aposdisgusting vile dumpapos that serves aposfag ash chickenapos. Through the door, and the place is clean, modern, airy. Not the windowless basement abattoir I expected. At the till, the cashier and I struggle to hear each other over the din of the kitchens. The vats hum loud and low under the clanking metal and beeps of ovens. £. for a vegan burger, it doesnapost come with chips, and aposthereaposs no lettuce, supply shortage...have we got a vegan burger...last one... your lucky day.apos £. for a bag of chicken and a tiny bag of chips. I turn to my sorry looking vegan burger and choose the plant-based, lettuce-less substitute as my first victim. And itaposs not all that bad really. Yes, some greenery would be nice, but this is certainly worth more than a one-star review, eventhe price made me squirm and the lack of chips was befuddling.Any optimism that the plucky wee Quorn burger fostered was extinguished by the pint of grease that was to follow, as I turned to the chicken. Though I will never , I was surprised to find a clean, pleasant establishment, a thoroughly okay place. Itaposs just a shame that they forgot to tell the food. news uk-news kate-middleton-ditched-one-thing-"Kate Middleton takes part in lesson at school in HarrowByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Jan | commentsThe Duchess of Cambridge is often regarded as one of the best-dressed royals as well as being full of poise and elegance. But that wasnapost always the case for Kate, who celebrates her th birthday tomorrow. As a teenager, she is said to have been shy and low in confidence after experiencing a tough time at school. When she was , she left that school and went to the prestigious £,-a-year Malborough College in . School pal Gemma Williamson previously told the Daily Mail: “Apparently she had been bullied very badly and she certainly looked thin and pale. She had very little confidence.”  However, at Marlborough, she sought solace in playing sports and then experienced a sudden turnaround that left every boy in the school rather flustered. And that turnaround is said to have come when Kate ed from the summer break aged . Gemma revealed that, after impressing school pals playing hockey and going cross-country running, the future duchess became “an absolute beauty” and “every boy in the school fancied her rotten”.  Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up . Her former teacher, Denise Alford, also revealed that Kate was able to transform her look after losing one key thing - her childhood braces. “Pippa was a tomboy but Kate had lost her braces and looked stunning, she told the Mail. “She was apparently top of the ‘Fit List’ which boys would sometimes pin on the walls.  When Kate left Marlborough with three A-Levels, she embarked on a gap year before deciding to attend St Andrews University, where she met her future husband, Prince William. There Kateaposs self-confidence famously won over William when she wore a see-through dress at a fashion show. In , the then -year-old prince reportedly spent £ for a front-row ticket for the charity fashion show his future we featured in. Here he saw Kate walking the catwalk in a see-through lace dress revealing her black underwear underneath. The duchess is said to have made the transformation from Williamaposs friend to his love interest after he saw her in the fashion show and said: Wow, Kateaposs hot. That started their romance, and now  years on the pair have been married for almost  years and have three gorgeous children Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis. title: kate middleton similarities diana how
story: Kate Middleton has similarities to Diana in how she cares for kids, expert claimsBody language expert Darren Stanton said Kate Middleton has changed while in the Royal limelight and says she has become a "relatable mum" who displays caring characteristicsKate Middleton with Prince George Image: Getty ImagesByGraeme Murray:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsKate Middleton has evolved as she prepares to celebrate her landmark th birthday, an expert in body language says.The Duchess of Cambridge turns  this weekend and during that time she has become a public figure in the worldaposs best known families.He said she displayed similarities to Princess Diana and she has grown into the role of being a Royal mother and all the responsibilities it entails.Body language expert Darren Stanton looked at how how Kate has changed while in the Royal limelight and says she has become a relatable mum who displays displaying caring characteristics which Princess Diana also showed.He said Kate’s maternal side had evolved since motherhood bringing her more gravitas as an established member of the Royal family.  Darren told bemybet: “Kate Middleton has been a very permanent member of the Royal family since she first began dating Prince William nearly  years ago and as she approaches her th birthday, it’s clear to see how her style has evolved over the years as she’s established herself as a royal.” In the previous ten years Kate has become a mother who has brought three children into the world along with William. This has allowed her to display her family skills which have continually developed as she became a respected member of the renowned family. He added: “Her maternal instinct is often displayed through her body language, which too has evolved as she’s got older. “In many photos and video clips, Kate is seen kneeling down to the height of her children when she is talking to them - a gesture that is both nurturing and protective.  But he also pointed out that she is not afraid to scold the children and has taken Princess Charlotte to task in photosshe was was misbehaving. Other members of the family may not be comfortable doing this in public, but Mr Stanton claims Kate’s body language remains open and transparent. He says she is happy to deal with all things have to deal with while raising a family and is open and honest about it. The expert also said Kate openly displays affection to her children which Princess Diana was known for. Traditionally, the Royal children would be chaperoned while their parents carry out public engagements but, Mr Stanton says she and Prince William prefer to be more hands on with their family. The behavioural expert described her as similar to Diana. He said some aposcelebritiesapos and other Royal family members can appear like they are not being genuine, but the same cannot be said for the Duchess of Cambridge. He described Kate as being happy to provide support to others and says it shows she cares. news uk-news kate-middleton-wears-earrings-owned-"Kate Middleton: Photo gives rare glimpse inside duchess’ handbagByGeraldine McKelvieInvestigations Editor:,  Jan | commentsThe Duchess of Cambridge gets all dressed up in stunning red to celebrate a ruby anniversary – her th birthday on Sunday. The off-the-shoulder number was one of three dresses Kate wore for photos to mark the occasion, all by fashion house Alexander McQueen, which made her  bridal gown. In two shots, Kate teams flowing white frocks with earrings owned by Princess Diana. The gems she wears with her scarlet gown were borrowed from the Queen. And in all the portraits, she goes for a natural English rose look in light make-up. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter  Photographer Paolo Roversi seemed quite star-struck by the birthday girl. He said: “Taking the portrait of Her Royal Highness, The Duchess of Cambridge, was a true honour for me, and a moment of pure joy. “I was moved by her warmth and friendly welcome and enchanted by her shining eyes that reflected the loveliness of her soul and her smile showing the generosity of her heart. “It was a profound and rich experience for me, an unforgettable moment. I have met a wonderful person, a person who, with her positive energy, can bring hope to the whole world.” The photos, part of the National Portrait Gallery’s Coming Home exhibition, will go on display in Berkshire, where Kate grew up, St Andrews, where she met Prince William, and Anglesey, their first marital home. title: mcdonalds fan left physically sick
story: McDonalds fan left physically sick after putting a Big Mac burger in an air fryerThe man, who goes by the name @Klobstar on Twitter, documented the whole process on the social media , in a thread which has now gone viralIn a clip, the bloke revealed the severity of the hardness by bashing the top with a spatula Image: MENByRachel Pugh:,  Jan | commentsA fast-food enthusiast was left feeling unwell after testing out what would happenhe put a McDonaldaposs Big Mac in an air fryer.The man, who goes by the name @Klobstar on Twitter, documented the whole process on the social media , in a thread which has now gone viral. Turning up the temperature on the appliance to  degrees Fahrenheit, the man put the burger in the appliance and put a timer on for one hour to begin with, reported Manchester Evening News.The first  minutes elapsed but the burger seemed untouched apart from a light toast on top of the bun. The Twitter user said: “I sense I’ll be learning more about bread science than hamburger science.” But the heat from the air fryer quickly kicked in - making the burger rock hard in  minutes. In a clip, the bloke revealed the severity of the hardness by bashing the top with a spatula.  And after half an hour - the fryer was not doing the greasy food any justice. He said: “The smell is pretty strange, but not overpowering, strong ketchup sauce smell that’s described as “not great”.” With only  minutes passing since the last check in, the scent of the burger seemed to get a lot more potent. “The smell. It has become worse. It is strangely sweet-smelling, with a hint of fire, the foodie said. Unfortunately, the aroma of the Big Mac continued to overpower the house at the -minute mark. The thread continues: “Oh god the smell in the last few minutes has become thick, it’s vaguely tomato-ey and I can smell it across the house. “Air fryer is working, but I fear I may be buying a new one when my we finds out.” As the burger hit the halfway mark, it appeared not to have changed much apart from being “a bit darker, a lot harder. The burger lover claimed: “The inside remains nearly untouched.” But the bloke may have spoken too soon, as the inside of the burger started to wilt in the last hour. He added: “The cheese has become the consistency and colour of cheap peanut butter and is bubbling oil. “It has reached the texture of plastic, and the smell is best described as “hot ketchup” I am confident I will have to go past two hours for any real results. “It now strongly smells like fire and my we has opened all the windows and the front door.” With only  minutes to go, the food scientist had to whisk the experiment outside due to the “demonic” stench of the burger. As the burger sizzled away in the air fryer outside, he considered carrying out his findings for longer. He said: “ minutes remain and I am seriously considering an extra hour without the bun, which seems to be such good insulation it may overtake that delicious pink stuff in houses as two hours comes to a close, I am astounded that this is for sure still edible.” After deciding to stop the experiment after two hours, the Twitter user surprisingly found that the inside was still mostly unaltered. He said: “It appears the inside of the hamburger is relatively untouched and is very soft. Smells somewhat like homemade meatloaf.” He decided to cut into the burger and consume the well-cooked food. And the verdict  “It was terrible, absolutely disgusting”, the man added. But despite the scathing review, the bloke still rewarded the charred burger a “  stars.” However, the Big Mac enthusiast may be regretting his scientic experiment. He added: “It’s been about  minutes since I ate a bite of the hamburger, it is not agreeing with my stomach. I may have made a mistake.” Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON McDonalds CorporationViral" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: meet grid brits dodging energy
story: Exclusive: Meet off-grid Brits dodging energy bill hikes - from family-of-four to City bankerHouseholds across the country are set to be hammered by soaring energy bills this year - but the hikes will have no impact on these Brits who have gone off-gridLindsay Banks is saving thousands by living off-grid Image: Hull News  PictureByGraeme CullordDan HallFeatures Writer:,  Jan | commentsEnergy bills are set to rocket as wholesale costs hit record highs but some savvy Brits are dodging the price hikes by going off-grid.Thousands have already made the switch, so don’t rely on public utilities for electricity, gas or water. And that’s a move that may well pay off in April when gas and electricity bills are expected to shoot up by %. The looming price crisis is linked to a surge in wholesale energy costs. A big rise in energy bills is expected on April  after the price cap for households on default tarfs jumps. However, the price hikes won’t affect the , people in the UK who generate their own power and heating. Nick Rosen, who has been living off-grid for more than  years, reckons the number of people turning their backs on household bills has doubled in a decade. The author of How to Live Off-Grid and founder of Off-Grid.net said: “Some people go off-grid to save money, others do it because they’ve had enough of consumer society, then there’s people who are doing it for the environment. “But ultimately, its about freedom.” Here, we speak to four off-grid Brits who will never again have to worry about expensive energy bills. Ex-city banker in Portuguese wilderness  After saving £, in two years, former City banker Laurence Manchee went off-grid in . The -year-old and his we Kimberly, , now live in the wilderness in central Portugal. As part of his new lestyle, Laurence has to work seven days a week. But he reckons he can live like a king on just £, a year, which he makes from selling eggs, cheese and meat. He said: “It’s about living in nature and not having to commute to work. “We have to make money but we do it in our own time and you don’t need much to live, so you’re not just working to pay rent and the bills. We are now about as far off-grid as you can get and we have everything here now. “We do everything off the sun through the solar . “You grow your own meat and vegetables and whatever you don’t have can be traded with other people living off-grid. “You feel much more connected to everything because you are not buying what you need – you make it. “It’s a healthier lestyle and it’s much better for the environment.” Laurence, whose nearest village is Mata Da Rainha, added: “In Portugal, property is so cheap so when people want to do it, they come here. “It’s ridiculous. When you go to the DIY store, it’s full of English people buying tools to live off-grid. “You can buy a bit of land in the middle of nowhere and stick a caravan on it for £, soyou’ve got ten grand, you can be mortgage-free.” Family-of- in converted horse box  Initially, Matthew Watkinson just wanted a nice place to take his kids on holiday when he bought land in Wales in . But he soon decided to ditch his Essex home and go off-grid. The -year-old now lives in a converted horse box on a farm with we Charis, , and kids Elsa, seven, and four-year-old Billy. It was created under the Welsh government’s One Planet Development scheme, which allows homes to be built on agricultural land outside normal planning areasthey satisfy certain criteria. The family grow a lot of their own food, generate electricity from solar and wind power and make gas from food waste.  They also make money by selling eggs and honey, cleaning and teaching others how to live off-grid. Former vet Matthew reckons the cost of building the family home, near Newport, Pembrokeshire, was about £,. He says: “We still pay council tax, internet and for mobile phones, but there are zero utility bills. I love it – and getting rid of all those bills is brilliant.”See more of the Watkinsons’ off-grid le on Instagram @beeviewfarmingDivorcee in an £, caravan  Self-employed writer Lindsay, , lives semi-off grid in an £, caravan. Before she officially made the switch last June, the mum-of-two struggled to make ends meet.But Lindsay, who is on Universal Credit, has since cut her bills from over £, a month to £ in land rent and still has all the mod cons she used to enjoy in her three-bed semi.Lindsay, , who got orced in , said: “The houses I was looking at cost £ a month plus bills. I was paying about £ a month to heat my three-bed semi… the financial pressure was intense. “There were some landlords that just said no because I am self-employed. I felt discriminated against and thought, ‘Why am I working so hard to pay into a system that feels broken anyway ’”After buying a caravan on Facebook Marketplace, Lindsay, who is originally from Newcastle, moved to a patch of land near York with her children, who are aged seven and .She said: “Since I’ve moved on site I’ve gone through one Calor gas bottle that cost £. “We have mains electric that goes straight into the caravan and I have a lovely electric heater that is , watts at its max. The cost of electric is included in the rent of £ a week. “I don’t have the money to buy my own site right now, but I’m working towards that.” Tree surgeon and girlfriend living wild  The thud of bills being shoved through the letterbox is not a sound that troubles Matthew Plumb and his girlfriend Lauren Youngs. Eventhe tree surgeon did receive mail – which he does not – his monthly outgoings for heat, electric, water and rent amount to less than £. Matthew, , and Lauren, , have been living wild in a shepherd’s hut for four years with their cat, Baby. He said: “It’s mental how much money you can save. I spend nothing on rent, zero on electric as we get all we need from solar  and about £ every six weeks on propane gas. I have four pigs that I breed and  chickens we use for meat and eggs.” Matthew told how the couple are also planning for the future and building another room to be a kitchen lounge. Speaking from the woods where they live in Monmouthshire, South East Wales, he added: “We want to start a family and for our kids to live a healthier and happier lestyle than many people get in the modern world. “More and more people are taking an interest in going off-grid. I think the pandemic has been a wake-up call.”Follow the couple on Instagram @bleu_jean_ @twometresplumbRead MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON EnergyCouncil taxEnergy billsSave moneyStarting a familySolar powerSunday Mirror" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our money-saving tips and top offers direct to your inbox with the Mirror Money newsletterInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: modern day vera lynn cheering
story: Exclusive: Modern day Vera Lynn cheering up Covid Britons just like Forces SweetheartLike her hero Vera Lynn, Annie Riley wants to lt the spirits of veterans and care home residents so has toured the country performing her songsAnnie Riley performing at The Not Forgotten Image: Muse PhotographicByEmma PryerSenior Writer:,  Jan | commentsA singer has lted the spirits of thousands of Covid-weary Brits – spurred on by the words of Forces Sweetheart Dame Vera Lynn. Annie Riley has toured theand breadth of the country, performing for ­veterans and care home residents. Her mission – just like Dame Vera’s We’ll Meet Again wartime anthem in the s – is to help people “keep smiling through”. And it was a pep talk from Dame Vera – who she first met  years ago – which encouraged Annie to pull out all the stops. Annie recalls Vera tenderly taking her hand and declaring: “Promise me that so long as you have air in your lungs, you will sing and share that singing with others.”  They met when Annie sang at a concert and it spawned a friendship that lasted until Vera died in June , aged . Last year, Annie, , and a band of song and dance entertainers working for charity The Not Forgotten did the star proud by performing for more than , Forces veterans and putting on socially-distanced shows at  care homes. Annie also helped organise  drive-in concerts for The Not Forgotten, which runs events to bolster the morale of wounded, sick or disabled veterans.  Her tireless enthusiasm has even earned her a thumbs-up from a royal namesake – the charity’s patron, Princess Anne. One of the drive-ins was at the Princess Royal’s -acre estate in Gatcombe Park, Glos – and Annie was in charge of the Christmas party entertainment at St James’s Palace. Mum-of-two Annie, from Charing, Kent, said: “The pandemic felt like my calling. I was feeling menopausal and thinking, ‘What am I going to do to help ’ and then it was clear. I knew I couldn’t stop entertaining because helping people and cheering them up is like oxygen to me. “Bless her heart, Vera really knew how important music was to people.  “I would never, ever compare myself with such a legend. But I thought about all the joy she spread during the war and when the pandemic started I thought, ‘This is my time to do something’.” Ex-pub singer Annie got a break with the s song duo Swingtime Sweethearts over  years ago. She and pal Le’arna Castle first performed in front of Dame Vera in . But they went one better a year later – recording the single Not Forgotten with Vera. They became ambassadors for one of her charities and helped organise her th birthday celebration in  with a concert at the London Palladium.The singers have also rubbed shoulders with Strictly Come Dancing ’s Anton Du Beke and celebrity chef Phil Vickery.Annie’s pandemic shows for The Not Forgotten started online in March . She also helped the charity set up YouTube music and message videos to connect with veterans, and a raft of stars contributed.  Annie – married to former pro wrestler John,  – said: “Dame Vera sent a message. Russell Watson sent footage of him singing with his dog. Sir Clf Richard sent footage from Barbados and some pre-recorded videos.“Brian May performed We’ll Meet Again on his guitar. Peter Andre and Jeremy Vine got involved, and Elaine Page, and some cast of the sitcom ’Allo ’Allo, who I have worked with, were also keen to help.”The videos were seen by more than , people. And not a single “hit” is not lost on Annie, who said: “You can’t change the world but you can change somebody’s world.”  When lockdown eased, Annie and her fellow entertainers kicked off their -gig care home tour. Each event ­represented a year of The Not Forgotten’s centenary. Annie added: “Sadly, I’ve met veterans with PTSD who thought of taking their own lives and I heard even more of that during the pandemic. Some have said, ‘You have saved me’ just by spreading that bit of joy. “I was at one home when a lady came up and said, ‘Thank you. You have given me my mother back for an hour’.  She could see the old mother had ed, dancing and enjoying the music. It was ­overwhelming to hear that. “We were all tearing up. Of everything I’ve done in my le – including performing in front of the Queen at the Palladium ­concert – nothing compares with knowing the good we’ve done in those homes. “At St James’s Palace, Princess Anne turned to me and said, ‘I’m so thrilled with what the charity has achieved in the most dficult of years’.”  Two years ago, Annie worked with Good Morning Britain on a loneliness prevention campaign – an issue close to her heart. She said: “I’ve always cared about the older generation. My dad died when I was young. I was brought up by my grandparents and mother. I’d sit on grandad John’s knee and sing. “When he got Alzheimer’s, he had to be put in a care home. When I visited it was like God’s waiting room, so I had to do something – and I volunteered to sing. Before I knew it, I was singing five days a week at dferent homes. Grandad died  years ago but when the pandemic hit I knew I had to keep cheering the elderly on.” At one event, Annie met a woman whose son was left disabled after being wounded on duty with the Royal Marines. The mum was in tears of joy at seeing him dancing.  Annie said: “I could see what a big thing that was. That sums it up for me. The Not Forgotten concerts take a bad situation and add a bit of sunshine to people’s lives – that there is light within the darkness. “We’re hoping to do more in . We just want to put smiles on people’s faces.” You can help The Not Forgotten at thenotforgotten.org support-us donate Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterComment MORE ON Vera LynnPhil VickeryAnne, Princess RoyalNursing homesAlzheimers disease" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get our daily royal round-up direct to your inboxInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: more 65000 raised memory student
story: More than £, raised in memory of student Harvey Parker found dead in River ThamesHarvey Parker, , tragically died after going missing following a night out at Heaven nightclub in Charing Cross, central London, on December Tributes have been paid to Harvey Parker following his death in London Image: Met policeByErtan Karpazli:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan More than £, has been raised in memory of a popular student whose body was found in the River Thames this week. Harvey Parker, , tragically died after going missing following a night out at a club in Charing Cross, central London on December . On Tuesday Harveyaposs body was recovered from the River Thames near Embankment, Westminster, not far from where he was last seen. His family is now fundraising to “support the work of the communities he was part of”.A JustGiving fundraising page commemorating Harvey has been inundated with wellwishers, MyLondon reports. “Money raised will go to young queer support groups, neuroerse and gender erse young people whoaposd benefit from emotional or mental health support and to help support talented musicians from under-represented communities,” the family said. “We want to ensure that others like Harvey are able to shine as brightly”. The campaign initially set out to raise £, in donations, but less than a day into it being launched, the campaign has already raised over three times as much with the help of some , donors. Leaving a message of support, one donor said: “Over  donations in such a short space of time. I think that says so much”. Harvey was a music student at the University of York. At this present moment in time, Harvey’s death is being treated as unexplained. Detective Chief Inspector Lucy OaposConnor, of the Central South Command Unit, said: We are providing Harveyaposs family with all the available information. We are also asking for media to please respect the familyaposs privacy at this challenging and dficult time.To donate to the fundraising appeal, click here Most Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON CharitiesEducationMental health" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: mum addicted being surrogate expecting
story: Mum addicted to being surrogate expecting th baby says its best job in worldLast year, Laura McCarthy, from Huddersfield, gave birth to someone s twins and is now planning to have her th baby, saying its addictive and the best job in the worldLaura gave birth to twins for another couple in ByHollie BoneNews ReporterAndrew Robinson:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | comments A mum who says being a surrogate is addictive is preparing to have her th baby.Laura McCarthy, , has four children of her own and has carried five others for parents unable to have their own children. After becoming a surrogate for the first time  years ago, the mum of four says the feeling of handing over the baby and seeing the coupleaposs instant and unconditional love for the child can be addictive. All of her surrogate pregnancies have been through in vitro fertilisation , meaning the coupleaposs fertilised egg is implanted in Lauraaposs womb so genetically none of the babies are hers.The single mum from Bradley, Huddersfield, told ExaminerLive : I love being a mum, it’s the best job in the world, and I love that I can help someone fulfil their dream to become a parent. Speaking of the moment she gets to pass the newborn over to the intended parents, she said: Once you see the baby in their arms you can see that unconditional love immediately. It is just so worth it. That feeling can be slightly addictive. Inspired by a TV programme, mum to April, , Rowan, , Ada, six, and Eira, two, decided to become a surrogate for the first time after the births of her first two children. That unconditional love that I felt, I thought how lucky I was to have that and so thoughtI could help others, then why not  Once they are old enough they will know who I am and that they grew in my tummy. She said. A decade on, she recently lost over st so that she could carry on and have a tenth baby for a single man with a donated egg, but is yet to become pregnant.  Laura who now weighs st explained: Having had nine babies, and definitely wanting more, I couldn’t risk a tenth baby whilst being so overweight because of the associated risk factors. Before starting the process, Laura gets to know the intended parents she is working with and stays in touch afterwards, adding that when the children are old enough they will be told how they were born. Once they are old enough they will know who I am and that they grew in my tummy. Laura adds. However there are misconceptions around surrogacy Laura says, including myths that surrogates make lots of money and concerns that they will become attached to the baby. People think I would be attached to the baby. Of course, I want to keep that baby safe, but you donapost have the same feelingstowards your own child when you are pregnant with someone aposs. She says.  Under UK law, surrogates cannot be paid except for reasonable expenses such as clothes and medication. In the UK, surrogacy is altruistic. Expenses are covered, such as travel and maternity clothes. Laura says, adding that some people ask funny questions like aposdo you know who you are doing it for apos. Yes, I would not have a baby for a stranger. she answers. But there are some concerns more personal to Laura as the number of children she has given birth to approaches double figures. Laura said: I do get asked that. It is a sensible question.  I would like to carry on helping people to have their family. If my body gets to the stage where it is struggling with pregnancy, orI get health problems or the birth is not going well, that is where a line will need to be drawn because my children need a mum.I never rule anything out, I play everything by ear. I have always coped well with pregnancy and have had straightforward births. Despite some initial shock and concern from her grandparents over her first surrogate baby, Laura says she has the full backing of her family, who would be surprisedshe stopped. Itaposs so normal to my family they would be shockedI wasnapost having more...my mum is my biggest support regarding surrogacy. She supports me in doing what I do. She added: Twelve years ago, when I first started to do it, they had a lot of misconceptions. They were a little bit shocked and thought I shouldnapost do it. They saw an amazing journey with the parents and how they were respectful of me. title: mum who weighed 17st sheds
story: Mum who weighed st sheds an incredible st in  months after hating how she lookedNikki Panner had tried many dferent diets in the past but never found one that worked for her as she hadnt taken the time to cook for herself and her familyNikki has shed an incredible six stone Image: Nikki Panner Slimming WorldByRachael DavisGraeme Murray:,  Jan Updated:,  Jan | commentsA mum shed an incredible six stones in eight months. after hating how she looked. Nikki Panner weighed more than  stonesand was unhappy in her own skin. She was desperate for some lovely pictures with her then-three-month-old daughter, but hated seeing herself. The -year-old mum had struggled with her weight and couldnapost look at herself.Nikki told MyLondon she had tried dferent diets and struggled to find one which worked for her.She said: I remember that Christmas We were taking photos, and I just did not like myself. In one photo, I hated myself in it. Iaposd been struggling with my weight for a few years at that point, I just wanted to feel happy.Following a suggestion from her mum, Nikki signed up to her local Slimming World group to begin her weight loss journey.Sheaposd tried many dferent diets in the past but never found one that worked for her, partly because sheaposd never really taken the time to cook for herself and her family, or spend time preparing nutritious, tasty meals. I barely cooked before, I never really took the time to, she explained. I [also] wasnapost really active at that point: Iaposd had a C-section and I had quite a bad recovery, so I couldnapost be too active. But I had time in the evening where I was able to just cook, so I found loads of Slimming World recipes that had what we call aposfree foodapos. I spent that time for myself cooking dinner for my family. Slimming Worldaposs aposfree foodsapos are healthy staples that make up the bulk of a nutritious meal, and members are encouraged to eat as much aposfree foodapos as they like, until they feel full. They include things like lean meat and meat replacements, fish, dairy, eggs, pasta, rice, potatoes, vegetables and fruit - the main healthy food groups that are incorporated into a balanced meal. Nikki, from Hillingdon, west London, said: It was just small changes in the foods I was eating, the way I prepared food, and it just fit into my lestyle. They were average meals that weaposd have every day beforehand, but I learned how to cook them better. I started to really enjoy it, to learn [how to cook], it taught me a lot long-term and changed the way I looked at food. No foods are banned, so I never felt like I was restricted, she added. When I joined [Slimming World] I was breastfeeding, and obviously I needed extra calcium and fibre so Slimming World added that into my plans, I never felt like I had to give up or sacrice anything - I could even have a chocolate barI needed to. As Nikki started to sht the pounds through enjoying a balanced diet of nutritious, filling meals - and still enjoying the odd treat to avoid unsustainable, restrictive dieting - she felt able to be more active and found it easier to move more. She began walking with her daughter as a relaxed way to exercise, and appreciated not feeling forced to go to the gym or endure strenuous exercise by her slimming plan. Her weight loss didnapost feel real until she saw photos of herself after losing around five stone. She noticed a stark dference in how she looked compared to the photos she hated from Christmas, and started to feel more confident in her own skin. After reforming her diet in January , by August Nikki had lost six stone, or  kilograms. This hasnapost only transformed her body image, but also her family le: losing the weight helped Nikki, who has polycystic oy syndrome , conceive her second child. Getting pregnant is dficult for people with PCOS, and one of the main symptoms of the condition is weight gain, which can make it even harder. Losing so much weight is, therefore, a twofold success for Nikki, who feels happier and healthier while getting ready to welcome another child into the world. My doctors said it was going to be really dficult for me [to get pregnant], but I think losing the weight really helped, she said.Iaposm already noticing a dference in this pregnancy : Iaposm going up the stairs so much quicker, I just feel more active, which is really nice.While Nikki continues her new lestyle, sheaposs also about to embark on a new career as a Slimming World consultant, helping other people achieve their goals - she couldnapost be more excited about her new job, or more proud of how far sheaposs come. title: novak djokovics behaviour pathetic should
story: Novak Djokovics behaviour is pathetic - he should set an example, not act like a bratI have absolutely no sympathy for Anti-vaxxer Novak Djokovic – the multi-millionaire sportsman now being compared to Jesus because of his victimisation, writes Rachael BletchlyDjokovic may be stuck in a grotty hotel room rather than the * palaces he’s used to, but at least he has a bed, a shower and hot meals, says our columnist Image: AFP via Getty ImagesopinionByRachael Bletchly:,  Jan | comments I suppose I ought to have sympathy for tennis ace Novak Djokovic, having once been in his shoes.In  I had my own immigration hiccup - in America - and after a frightening and humiliating -hour ordeal I was kicked out of the country. I wasn’t trying to sneak in or bend the rules. It was a genuine mistake. I’d been sent to Los Angeles on a story but didn’t know rules had changed post   and that foreign journalists needed visas to work in the US. I was held at passport control, had my phone confiscated and was fingerprinted and body-searched. I was moved to a tiny airless room for processing and held incommunicado without any update on my case. Finally Alien: Bletchly, Rachael, No  was marched in handcuffs to a plane door and removed from the Land of the Free. The officials were rude and I was treated appallingly. But I have absolutely no issue with the decision to deport me. I did not have the relevant documentation permitting me to work in the US. And rules are rules.  Anti-vaxxer Novak Djokovic thinks he should be allowed into Australia to defend his Open title without adhering to their strict Covid laws. His attempt to get round the issue with a “medical exemption” due to a recent Covid infection, is the worst kind of exceptionalism. So I’m afraid I have absolutely NO sympathy with Djokovic – the multi-millionaire sportsman now being compared to Jesus because of his victimisation. His family in Serbia claim the Aussies are trying to “crucy” him and use him as a political pawn. Come off it! Djokovic may be stuck in a grotty hotel room rather than the * palaces he’s used to, but at least he has a bed, a shower and hot meals. I had a row of hard plastic seats, wet wipes and a couple of stale sandwiches. Djokovic also has the enormous privilege of being a hero and role model to millions of young people. That makes his behaviour even more pathetic. He should set an example, not act like a brattish young McEnroe and kick off when things don’t go his way. As old rival Rafa Nadal said, Djokovic “knew the conditions a lot of months ago, so he made his own decision. I believe in what the people who know about medicine say - andthey say we need to get vaccinated, we need to get the vaccine”. Let’s hope young tennis fans follow in Rafa’s footsteps and give No-vax the contempt he deserves. title: pensioner 77 left despair after
story: Pensioner, , left in despair after leline scooter bought after heart attack stolenBill Green, , was playing Bingo at the Crows Nest pub in Longhill, Hull on Wednesday when a group of vandals stole his mobility scooter - which serves as a social leline while he is recovering from a traumatic cardiac arrest - from outside and trashed it beyond repairThe mobility scooter was a social leline for Bill Green, , as he recovered from a cardiac arrest Image: hulldailymailByJames CampbellRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Jan  An elderly man is in despair after a group of thugs stole and wrecked his mobility scooter which has been a social leline while he is recovering from a traumatic heart attack that nearly killed him. In May, Bill Green, , found himself unable to breathe and was rushed to AE where his heart stopped.But thankfully he survived and his relieved family were so elated they clubbed together to buy a mobility scooter - which would allow him to get out and about.Heaposs now distraught after this leline which helped him socialise was taken from outside the Crowaposs Nest pub in Longhill, Hull, where he was playing Bingo on Wednesday night, Hull Live reports.There are reports a group of youths took his scooter.His family and friends then searched the area for the scooter and it was found just a short distance away on Holderness Road and was trashed beyond repair.Bill’s daughter Julie Green, of Longhill, is now pleading for information to trace those responsible. My dad had gone to the Crow’s Nest pub to play bingo and he left his scooter outside,” she said. “The regulars who go out for a smoke always keep an eye on it but there was a short period when no one was outside and it was taken at around pm on Wednesday. “We all went searching for it and it was found at am the next day less than a mile away. It was completely smashed up.”  While the gratuitous act helped pass a few minutes of time for those involved, the impact will last much longer for Bill. “The scooter was a leline for my dad,” Julie said. “In May he could not breathe and he was taken to hospital by ambulance where his heart stopped. We were told by the medical staff he would not survive but somehow he did.Even after this, he ended up with Covid for  days. He now has a ventilator every night as he canapost get carbon dioxide out as his diaphragm is too weak.“His legs swelled up after and he cannot walk far anymore. “It was such a massive thing for us that he survived, we decided to all chip in and buy him a mobility scooter.” Not only has Bill lost the scooter, but he now also feels responsible for leaving it unattended. “The scooter has become very important to him and has become a le support,” Julie said. “We are all very, very frustrated. If they had taken it to sell and make money at least it would make more sense but what they have done is so pointless.  “They just took it and then destroyed it. We can’t understand why they have done this. “My dad now feels guilty for leaving it outside when everyone helped pay for it. “He has been crying over what happened and so have I. There has been a bit of good news after the family posted about the theft on social media. “After we put something on social media someone has kindly come forward and lent him a scooter for a few weeks but we don’t know what will happen after that,” Julie said “Unfortunately, the scooter was uninsured and we cannot afford to get him a new one. Julie has a message to those who stole and then trashed the scooter. “Why ” she said, “What have you gained from doing that  “It is just a pointless act that has taken an elderly man’s leline away. If my dad just ends up stuck in the house all day then he will go downhill massively.” Humberside Police are now appealing for anyone with information to come forward.A spokeswoman said: “We are investigating the theft of a mobility scooter which was reported as stolen from Douglas Road in Hull on Wednesday, January  between pm and pm. “The blue and black scooter was left securely outside and was stolen leaving the elderly owner very distressed and vulnerable. “The scooter was later found abandoned and damaged on Holderness Road. “We are appealing for anyone with information that would help identy the person who stole the scooter to call us on our non-emergency number  quoting reference   .”Julie has now organised a GoFundMe page to raise money for a new scooter which has already topped £,. If you would like to donate, click here.Read MoreRead MoreMost Read Dont MissFollow MirrorFacebookTwitterMORE ON Humberside PoliceHospitalsHeart attackHeart diseaseMental healthMobility scooterTeenagersArson" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you.
