title: Archbishop Desmond Tutu visited Newcastle
story: ARCHBISHOP Desmond Tutu, who died on Boxing Day, was one of the most recognised people in the world mdash as he proved when he came to Newcastle over  years ago.The archbishop, who was , won a Nobel Peace Prize for his role in the fight against apartheid in his native South Africa.Just a year after the release of Nelson Mandela, he came to Newcastle in April  to attend a meeting of Anglican Church leaders from around the world.Despite the presence of the newly appointed Archbishop of Canterbury, Dr George Carey, and the Church of Ireland primate, Archbishop Robin Eames, Archbishop Tutu was the star of the show.There was a media scrum when he arrived at the front door of the Slieve Donard Hotel, at once greeting the hordes of photographers and journalists with his radiant smile.Asked what it was like to be in Newcastle, the Archbishop, wearing a hat and coat to keep out the early spring wind and rain, quickly replied: ldquoItrsquos so cold here.Archbishop Tutu built up an instant rapport with the national and local media, which continued when he came to Downpatrick to visit St Patrickrsquos grave at Down Cathedral..prettyPhoto

title: Business case to pave way for parking at Castlewellan
story: A BUSINESS case is to be compiled to pave the way for a new car park facility at the Bann Road in Castlewellan to ease the pressure on town centre parking.Agreement to prepare the document came at last weekrsquos meeting of Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos Enterprise, Regeneration and Tourism Committee.Planning approval for the  space parking area which will also feature cycle racks and lighting has already been secured.At the recent council committee meeting, Slieve Croob councillors Roiacutesiacuten Howell and Cathy Mason urged the local authority and Department for Infrastructure to ensure that the project remains a priority for Castlewellan.Cllr Howell said the proposed car park will also feature a new entrance and fencing to make the area a safe, secure and modern facility for commuters and all those using the facility and that Sinn Fein will push to ensure its delivery.Cllr Mason said the parking facility will hopefully go some way to alleviating the pressure on town centre parking.ldquoNot only will the new facility be ideal for commuters car sharing, but be a great asset to those using the townrsquos forest park and local sports facilities on the Bann Road, she said.ldquoThe provision being made for cyclists will also be welcomed by the many visitors and tourists who come to the area for its scenic beauty and fabulous walking and cycling trails..prettyPhoto

title: Busy Boxing Day
story: GLENN Grant of Championchip Ireland provided the perfect reason for runners to get off the sofa on Boxing Day.He lined up two races ndash a K and a K ndash which were held in the Harbour Estate in Belfast and while the weather was unkind to say the least, the course was flat with a perfect surface and the roads were closed.It may not be everyonersquos ideal way to spend the morning after Christmas Day but close to  iniduals saw it as a way to offset their indulgence and perhaps make room for round two of festivities.The K started at .am on the dot. So punctual in fact that East Down ACrsquos Sharon Madine missed the start of that race and so she talked herself into doing the K as penance.There were  starters with plenty of quality runners at the front of the pack, who were obviously there to do more than merely run off the turkey.The top five men broke  minutes with Gerard Heaney of North Belfast Harriers taking the win in ..The fastest female was Dearbhla Cox of Annadale Striders in .. East Down had five entrants including three juniors.Oliver Robinson led the club home in . which is a massive  seconds faster than his previous best that was set in Victoria parkrun a few months. Jacob Crawford crossed the line in . showing that the consistent training is paying off and James Wright was delighted to breach  minutes and gain a new personal best time of ..These results are a great morale booster for the youngsters. Maureen Kellyensured that the family standards were upheld when she also bagged a personal best with ..Margueritesaid that it took at least until halfway to thaw her frozen hands and she was glad to see the finish line looming.She was happy enough with her time of . and even happier to jump in the car and head home.In the K which began at .am there were  entrants. The top three finishers were in within the  minute barrier.In first place was Ben Branaghin a time of ..The top female was Gillian McCrory, representing St Peterrsquos AC, in .. East Down AC had four runners, all female and as mentioned, Sharon Madine was only there by default.Having got lost en-route and failed to get to the K start, she felt that the only way to save face was to run the K.She actually ran very well and in the end was happy to have doubled her exercise goal for the day. Her time of . placed her as th female out of  and was not that far off her personal best.This is impressive since she prefers K to K and also that she arrived with no intention of racing that distance.In addition the blustery conditions were not ideal for chasing times. Alison and Ella Carroll opted for the K over the K based on the later start and the chance of a lie in.It turned out that the rain had also eased by then so it was a good call. Alison ran a well paced race and was as pleased with her consistent splits as she was with her time of ..Ella has not fitted much training in as of late but with characteristic grit she ploughed on to the finish in a time of ..Mags Flynn slipped across the line between these two in a very respectable ..It was a well organised event with adequate parking and toilets. All entrants received a t-shirt and medal and even the poor weather did not detract from the smug feeling of achievement for those who turned out. Kudos to Glenn Grant for his efforts to make this happen.Meanwhile closer to home, the rain had cleared early on to give a bright mild day. Gordy Graham was out for the Burren Townland ten miler and said it was almost too warm.The contrast in the photos of this compared to the Belfast meet is marked. Gordy had a great race and took the win by a clear margin in a time of . but he was keen to point out that his closest adversary, Brendan Heaney, was denied the chance to race it out when he took an unfortunate tumble.Gordy had the good grace to help his rival up but it seemed that the fall took its toll and Brendan never really got back on track.He did hold on to second place but he was four minutes behind Gordy in the end. Another podium for Gordy to end a successful year. It was no surprise to find that Niall Gibney was in the mountains on Boxing Day.However, this time instead of a solo escapade, he had signed up for the annual Turkey trot organised by BARF .This arduous run started at Meelmore Lodge then headed up the lane to the Mourne Wall. The climbing continued up to Trassey Track Ford and then up to the Bernagh-Meelmore col.Niall said that the paths were like mini streams after the deluge on Christmas Day and he described the river crossing below the col as ldquointeresting.To others that probably means practically impassable but the runners toiled on finally reaching Meelmore-Meelbeg Saddle.Our intrepid mountain man reported that, ldquoFrom here the brakes were off and it was a fun fast slippery downhill to the Happy Valley. A further treacherous stretch took them along the Mourne Way back to the lane to Meelmore Lodge.A run like this requires agility as well as stamina, so not all would be fit for the challenge and indeed it was a select field of  who set out. After , feet of climbing over . miles, Niall was pleased to make the top , placing th overall. Another challenge safely navigated..prettyPhoto

title: Christmas joy for couple as they welcome baby Cathail
story: A BALLYHORNAN couple have welcomed the birth of baby son Cathail on Christmas Day.He was one of the first babies to be born in Northern Ireland on the special day.Cathail is the first child of Emma Walsh and her partner James Cormican, who have just moved to Ballyhornan from Killough.Cathail was born at .am on Christmas morning at the Ulster Hospital in Dundonald, weighing in at an impressive lb oz.For new mum Emma, while Cathail was four days overdue, he still made a surprise appearance.She explained that while the couple were getting carpet laid in their new home on the Tullyronan Road on Christmas Eve morning, she experienced some early signs of labour.ldquoWe got the keys to our new house on Wednesday before Christmas and we just had literally moved in when I started having pains, explained  year-old Emma.ldquoWe joked that the reason that I went into labour was that the house was nearly finished and Cathail knew it was time to come.ldquoThe whole time I was pregnant, people would ask when I was due and I told them that knowing my luck I will be in on Christmas Day.ldquoI used to say that the baby would end up getting their Christmas presents and birthday presents all on the one day but that was just the day that Cathail decided to be born.Emma and James, a  year-old mechanic from Kilclief, travelled up to the hospital around pm on Christmas Eve.But while midwives confirmed that Emma was indeed in labour, the baby was unlikely to arrive at that time and she was sent home to rest.She explained: ldquoMy waters broke as soon as we got home around pm so we had to turn around and go back to hospital again.Emma was delighted that James was allowed to be with her throughout the labour and delivery.Both mother and baby were well enough to be allowed home later on Christmas Night where she and James enjoyed a late Christmas dinner courtesy of Emmarsquos parents.Baby Cathail was impeccably behaved on his first night at home.ldquoI said to James on Christmas Night, that this is not too badhe continues like this, but the second night he got going, laughed Emma.Emma is well known in the Downpatrick area from working in her father Charliersquos shop, Walshrsquos Costcutter, in the Flying Horse estate..prettyPhoto

title: Event raises £3k for Air Ambulance NI
story: A CHARITY tractor run in Ballynahinch over the Christmas holidays raised over pound, for Air Ambulance Northern Ireland.Robert McCormick organised the Ballylone Tractor Run as a thank you for the help he received after he was hit by a car near Lisburn last September.Mr McCormick, who suffered broken ribs and damaged an elbow in the accident, was attended by Air Ambulance personnel who arrived by car and took him to the Royal Victoria Hospital in Belfast.Mr McCormick said he had intended to hold the tractor run during the summer, but decided at the last minute to bring the event forward to last Tuesday.With only three days to make arrangements, his grandson Andrew got onto social media and spread the word. The High School Ballynahinch made its car park available for parking,Premier Traffic Systems lent some traffic cones and Stephen Wilson, of Truck and Plant Elex, volunteered to lead the tractors with his van.Permission to hold the run was obtained from the Parades Commission.ldquoTuesday morning came and to be honest we had no idea how many would turn up, Mr McCormick said. ldquoWe were hoping for  or at best , but it soon became clear we were in for a busy day.ldquoRegistration was at am, but the first batch of tractors, all the way from Ballywalter, arrived at .. From that until the run started there was just a steady flow of tractors. In total we had  tractors,  lorries and seven cars. This far exceeded what we dared to dream of.Gate receipts amounted to pound, and with further donations a total of pound, will be presented to the Air Ambulance.Mr McCormick said: ldquoI would like to give anyone who helped in any way and everyone who donated a massive thank you..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C  January 2%2C 1992
story: NEWCASTLE ndash A new strategy has been drawn up by the Planning Service to limit the number of hot food carry-outs and amusement arcades in Newcastle.The planners have placed an embargo on further application for food outlets and arcades within a specially mapped out zone in the town centre.Details of the new zone have been outlined to Down councillors who, together with the townrsquos Chamber of Commerce and some local traders, had expressed concern at the proleration of hot food carry-outs and amusement arcades sprouting up in the resort.However, the planners have approved two applications for carry-outs which had been used to highlight the problem. It will give the town a new Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurant and a health food outlet.Newcastle SDLP councillor, Mr Michael Boyd, said he ldquodeplored and regretted the decision to allow another two carry-outs.However, he appreciate the dficulty of the plannersrsquo position in that the two applications were received before a strategy existed and viewed the formulation of the strategy as the ldquolesser of two evils.ldquoNow the planners have agreed to a strategy to by known as the Newcastle enhancement strategy, in response to our concerns and questions, said Mr Boyd.DOWNPATRICK ndash The Gallows Hill area in Downpatrick is to be brought into public ownership, it has been revealed this week.Local SDLP MP, Mr Eddie McGrady, has announced that the Department of Environment has approved an application from Down District Council to upgrade one of the most historic sites in the town.ldquoI am pleased to announce that the Department has approved the councilrsquos application for open space grant which will entail grant up to  per cent of the purchase cost of land needed for passive recreation, said the South Down MP.ldquoThe Downpatrick Regeneration Project has also included an environmental improvement scheme at Gallows Hill in its submission for financial aid under the CRISP programme.ldquoI welcome these developments and hope that the area will eventually be upgraded and regenerated.DUNDRUM ndash Police believe two recent fires at Dundrum schools were caused by the same person.Detectives investigated malicious blazes as both Downshire and the Sacred Heart Primary Schools say the evidence points to the same person and they have appealed for information from the public.A Dundrum man, who was detained for questioning about the Sacred Heart blaze, has been released without charge.That latest fire occurred at the Sacred Heart primary on December  and came less than one wek after an arson attack caused damage estimated at over pound, at Downshire primary.Damage to the Sacred Heart school was confined to the assembly hall after residents spotted the blaze at around pm. The Fire Brigade managed to extinguish the fire before it caused serious damage, although one fireman at the scene said the floor and curtains were burning fiercely.The fire was started after someone entered the school through a skylight of the flat-roofed building. A bale of straw, which had been used for the schoolrsquos nativity scene and which was due to be taken away the next day, was used to start the fire.CASTLEWARD ndash Work is underway to restore the historic corn mill at Castleward to its former glory.The wheels of the th century mill, which were last used  years ago, should be back in operation next summer thanks to a pound, restoration project.The mill has not been in operation since the estate was sold by the Bangor family to the National Trust. However, a team of experts is currently bringing the mill back to working order and recreating what was once an essential part of estate le.The project is being co-ordinated by Dr Fred Hamond, a freelance industrial archaeologist, who outlined some of the history of the mill, beginning from when the strong ties of Strangford Lough were harnessed to turn the wheels.ldquoIt dates back to the s and was initially a tide mill. It was rebuilt in the early s on the same site, but instead of using the tide, it was powered by the force of the river, he said.Much work is needed before the mill is readily to grind corn once again.ldquoThe place was in a terrible condition and we have had to carry out a major cleaning job, Dr Hammond explained.Even so, the surroundings more than make up for the dirty conditions.ldquoIt has been lovely working here, even during the winter. We have an impressive wildfowl collection close at hand and the mill is situated beside the old farmyard and the original castle, he added.BALLYNAHINCH ndash The first phase of a pound, construction project at St Patrickrsquos Roman Catholic Church in Ballynahinch will get underway later this year.Work on a new parish centre in the grounds of the church is earmarked to begin in the spring.The two-storey building, which replaces the existing tin structure close to the nearly cemetery, will comprise a main hall to be used for parish s and indoor sports, a secondary hall, committee rooms, cloakrooms, kitchen and toilets.The second stage of the project ndash a major extension of the church which will increase its seating capacity to  ndash is expected to begin a completion of the first phase next year.Ballynahinch parish priest, Canon Bernard Smyth, said services will be held in the parish centre while the extension work is carried out.DOWN HIGH ndash Memories of almost  years at Down High School flooded back to Mrs Eleanor Carlisle when she was deluged with gts to mark her retirement as senior administrative officer.It was quite a day for her when she was the guest of the headmaster, Mr Jack Ferris, and staff at their Christmas lunch at the Millbrook Lodge Hotel, Ballynahinch.It was her first and only job. She enjoyed every moment of it. When she married John Carlisle and raised a family, she came back in .She recalls pupils of her early days, recalls meeting their children at the same school office and, in a few cases, third generations.ldquoYes, Irsquoll miss this place and the thousands of young people that Irsquove come to know every closely, indeed very personally, she said resignedly.On reflection, she reckons that she learned by experience to accommodate all the changes introduced to the administrative system without every having to attend courses.GAA mdash Downpatrick are Downrsquos double champions. The men from the RGU were crowned league champs on Sunday for the first time in  years to add to their championship title.The toughest prize in local gaelic football has eluded the green and whites for nearly half-a-century, but they collected the trophy with a blistering victory over Burren - to -.And the man with the broadest smile at Dunleath Park was this yearrsquos East Down Hall of Fame winner, Bernard Deeny.It was the motion from Bernard and sponsored by the Downpatrick club to the Down County Convention in  that set up the first Down all-county senior football league.To make it a sweet year for Downpatrick, they were the winners of that first ever all-county league.Meanwhile, Conor Deegan, Barry Breen, Gregory Blaney and Ross Carr, four of Downrsquos magnicent Sam Maguire Cup winning players, picked up Bank of Ireland Allstar awards.But Down, as all-Ireland champions, must be sickened by the net result. Meath, beaten finalists, received six awards Leinster champions Dublin got three and Roscommon and Kildare received one apiece..prettyPhoto

title: Health advisor Enya receives recognition
story: A MAJOR award has been won by a health and safety advisor for the South Eastern Health and Social Care Trust.Enya McNally was awarded the John Gordon Safety Person of the Year accolade by the Safety Advice Centre Northern Ireland.She has been instrumental in recording Covid positive staff cases within the trust for the last year.The award is designed to celebrate the inidual who has made the greatest contribution to health and safety in their workplace in the past year and who goes above and beyond in their role in the pursuit of good health and safety.Enya took up employment with the Trust in September  during the Covid  pandemic at a time when there was immense pressure on the system.She adapted to her role in a large organisation very quickly making herself known to stakeholders both within and external to the Trust.She is recognised for having an ldquoimmense energy and passion for health and safety ensuring she underpins decision making with legislation and current best practice and is always willing to engage and support staff across the trust and is keen to proactively introduce new ideas to improve practice.Valerie Walker, Head of Risk Management Advisory Services for the Trust, said: ldquoEnya has launched herself with enthusiasm into the role as healthand safety adviser. She has undertaken an improvement initiative to address the reporting under RIDDOR of Covid positive staff incidents in the trust, working with occupational health colleagues, regional health and safety managers and the Health  Safety Executive NI.ldquoShe has presented this to our executive management team, including our chief executive and other directors and is also sharing with other staff across the Trust.Praising Enya on her award, Bill McAllister, managing director of the Safety Advice Centre, said: ldquoI am delighted that Enya won this award during , a year in which the Safety Group received a record level of entries.ldquoEnyarsquos project on developing a reporting, investigation and management of Covid  issues procedure has signicantly benefited the Trust.ldquoThrough delivering the project, Enya exhibited an immense energy and passion, proactively engaging with ious stakeholders.He added: ldquoIt is obvious that Enya has a long and successful career ahead of her in the Trust working to protect the safety, health and wellbeing of staff and others..prettyPhoto

title: Magnificent turnout for Christmas Cracker race
story: THERE was much anticipation in the build-up to race day as uncertainty in the midst of a new iant of the Covid- virus had everyone on edge.Thankfully, the race was allowed to proceed as planned and what a spectacle it turned out to be. Registration had opened months in advance and entries sold out in record time, a clear indication that this race has become a firm favourite for the elite and the not so elite runner.For most, it is the sense of turning up on the day not knowing what to expect. The race has two unique selling points.Firstly, you have to run with a partner and you are only ever as good as your other half.Many alliances come unstuck on the hills and in the mud and friendships are often lost, regained and lost again as the race unfolds.Secondly, and perhaps more uniquely, only a select few know the course in advance and they are sworn to secrecy.This is unusual in that most of us go to a race knowing what to expect in terms of distance, terrain and elevation: not so with this one.The only information is that it begins and ends in Castlewellan and it is between eight-and-a-half and nine miles .The course this year was a very tightly guarded secret with only those entrusted to assist with the marking on the eve of the race getting any real insight.When asked to describe the course, the Prophet simply stated: lsquoit will stun the legs and play with the headrsquo.These words rang in my head as I ran around fields that I never expected to, climbed hills that I never climbed before and at one point,my eyesight is not failing, saw Sherpa Tenzing throwing down ropes and herding a cabinet of yaks.At the business end of proceeding, there was some real class on parade with Irish mountain running sensation Zak Hannapaired with Andrew Annett , a man in great form as evidenced by his superb win in the Armagh Ten.This international pairing with real climbing pedigree firmly lived up to their billing as odds-on favourites and were almost three minutes ahead of their nearest challengers, the youthful pairing of Jared Martinand Tom Crudgington .With many years of running ahead, both these young men are capable of winning the race in the not-too-distant future.The podium was completed by the last minute pairing of Jonny Scottand Aaron McGrady , who hooked up on the morning of the event due to late withdrawals.The chemistry was clearly good and the partnership worked as they came home in just over  minutes ndash  seconds adrt of Martin and Crudgington.The ladiesrsquo race was a tighter affair with Amanda Perry and Denise Logue from Ballydrain winning by  seconds from Dearbhla Coxand Niamh Donnelly .The podium was completed by Clair Quigley and Fiona McQuillan .The mixed team event is always closely fought and this year was no dferent. With a mile to go to the finish, eventual winners Aidan Brownand Nakita Burkewere still under pressure from Stephen Connolly and Caitlyn Harvey from North Down AC.However, in the final twists and turns the former prevailed and ran out winners by around a minute, finishing eighth and tenth overall respectively.The podium was completed by Neil McGeough, Newcastlersquos rising star, and his partner, Irish Olympian Kerry OrsquoFlaherty, an athlete more at home on the track and over barriers than climbing ditches.Throughout the field there was great camaraderie and the craic was mighty. Social media was buzzing after the race with participants commenting that this was the best course they had ever ran over, despite the numerous challenges that it presented.The race organisers are indebted to everyone, too many to mention inidually, who contributed in any way to the success of the event.It brought great joy to those taking part and spectating at a time when anything that improves our well-being is something to celebrate..prettyPhoto

title: McCartan hopes for dream start back at the helm
story: DOWN manager James McCartan will be looking for a dream start to hisat the helm this Friday when his Mourne side take on Donegal in the first round of the Dr McKenna Cup.The red and black outfit will travel to MacCumhail Park for a .pm throw-in, in what will be the first piece of action for the county this year.The ing fan favourite will not be under any illusions as to the level of stf competition his footballers will face off against, as they travel to the home of last yearrsquos Ulster semi-finalists.Antrim are the other outfit that make up Section A, with Down welcoming the Saffrons to Newry in their second game next Tuesday.McCartan has already faced adversities in his second stint as boss before his team have even lined out, due to a number of regular Mourne players ruled out of contention.Carryduff duo James Guinness and Owen McCabe, Bryansford shot-stopper Marc Reid and experienced Burren duo Gerard McGovern and Donal OrsquoHare are among those unavailable.The former All-Star man in charge, alongside assistant Aidan OrsquoRourke, have already began drafting in suitable replacements and have recently been given a notable boost in the form of ing former captain Niall McParland.The Glenn clubman has ed following three years teaching in Doha, Qatar, and will be someone who McCartan looks to in order to bring his wealth of experience to the rest of the side ndashespecially those who are up and coming talents.ldquoThe squad has changed but itrsquos good to see some new faces in the , said McParland.ldquoJames and Aidan have a handle on everyone in the county and they have a good squad together so far.ldquoI was happy to get the call to go back because I didnrsquot knowI would get it ndash I donrsquot take anything for granted, he continued.ldquoNow Irsquom fighting for my place in the team.Alongside this encouraging news for the county, current star Barry OrsquoHagan believes Down could benefit even further from an influx of Kilcoo players.However, the current champions of Down are currently hoping to retain their Ulster title when they face off against Derrygonnelly on January , which will see them out of action until things unfold.With this meaning they will not be available for selection for the Dr McKenna Cup, this doesnrsquot necessarily rule out some of the  featuring in the Division Two league campaign.ldquoAt the minute, therersquos probably eight or nine of them you would definitely want in, said OrsquoHagan.ldquoWhether they commit or not I donrsquot know, itrsquos up to those men, but you need the talent and the experience those boys have.ldquoObviously their full focus is on Kilcoo at the minute, as yoursquod expect..prettyPhoto

title: Owenbeg are on title march
story: IT was an early Christmas present for Owenbeg with a double win over St Johnrsquos to keep their Division One title hopes on track.The current league champions still have three outstanding matches with league leaders Banbridge, so it is still all to play for in this ision.In Division Two, Drumaness kept their title hopes alive with their win over St Johnrsquos. However, current leaders Strangford still have outstanding matches with both clubs, so it is too close to call what way it will pan out.OWENBEG............................ST JOHNrsquoS.............................OWENBEG at home are a formidable outfit and although it was a comfortable victory in the end, St Johnrsquos made them work for their wins.Stevie Galbraith has been in outstanding form this season and got his team off to a good start with a straight game win over Marek Shotkevitch, whose style of play is not suited to low ceilings.John Huyton is slowing ing to his best form with a five games victory over Peter Deeny. Martin Pickles made it - for Owenbeg with his three game win over an improving Tom Garvey, who is clearly benefiting from competing against top players.The Downpatrick outfit reeled off the next four games to ensure the points with St Johnrsquosrsquo second win of the night coming from Shotkevitch via a close four game win over PeterDeeny.In thematch two days later at Newcastle, the teams produced a similar scoreline with the home sidersquos two wins coming from Marek Shotkevitch over Peter Deeny and Martin Pickles.ST JOHNrsquoS.............................DRUMANESS........................IN what was an entertaining Division Two match attended by the league secretary, Drumaness kept their title hopes alive in an exciting encounter that could have gone either way.Vincey Poland got his team off the mark with a four game win over Charlie Murray, but the consistent Hugh Scott evened the score with his four game victory over Sean Poland.Ann Poland has seldom played better this season and in the first of the close matches was just piped at the post in a nip and tuck fth games against Pat Mulholland that ended -.Vincey evened the score in another close five set game win over Pat Mulholland and Sean Poland gave another sterling performance to beat Charlie Murray - in the final game.St Johnrsquos were now in the driving seat and looked odds on to win this match.Hugh Scott needed to beat Ann Poland and was relieved to get home in four games, although he lost the next match to Vincey -.The two final games would decide the match. Pat Mulholland made it four apiece with his straight game victory over Sean Poland, with Ann Poland needing to beat Charlie Murray. It was a tense match with a relieved Murray just getting home with three points to spare.Ann may have lost this match but gave the best performanceof the season and rightly deserved the player of the night accolade..prettyPhoto

title: Portaferry man hailed a ‘lifesaver’
story: A PORTAFERRY man whose quick action saved a work colleague has been hailed as ldquothe right person at the right time.Paul Whitcombe has received a Royal Humane Societyrsquos Resuscitation Certicate for administering cardiac pulmonary resuscitation .He responded swtly to an emergency at his workplace at Falcon Way in South Belfast when a man collapsed and stopped breathing last May .Mr Whitcombe was called to help the man, along with other colleagues as they put him in the recovery position.He then contacted emergency services and began to perform CPR as the manrsquos pulse was not detected.Mr Whitcombe also gave the man mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, even though he had not any mouth protection.When a defibrillator was brought to the scene, he swtly used the device to shock the man and continued to perform CPR until an ambulance arrived.The stricken man was rushed to hospital where he recovered following surgery.Andrew Chapman, secretary of the Royal Humane Society, called Mr Whitcombe a lesaver.ldquoPaul stayed calm and did an amazing job. He was undoubtedly responsible for saving his colleaguersquos le, he said.ldquoHe was the right person in the right place at the right time, knew exactly what to do and carried out the treatment professionally. He richly deserves the award he is to receive.Mr Chapman stressed that the incident reinforced the need to ensure that more than just members of the emergency services learn CPR techniques.He continued: ldquoIrsquom sure everyone who learns it probably hopes they will never be called on to use it but as this case graphically shows it can, as it did here, make the dference between le and death.The Queen is the patron of the Royal Humane Society, which was founded in  by two eminent physicians, William Hawes and Thomas Cogan, who wanted to promote resuscitation techniques to counter the problem of some people being wrongly mistaken for dead..prettyPhoto

title: Seaforde swimmer given another major accolade
story: SEAFORDE golden girl Bethany Firth has been awarded an OBE in the New Year Honours.The  year-old, who has won six Paralympic gold medals, has been given the honour for her services to swimming.Bethany won two gold medals at the Tokyo Games to add to the four she won at previous Games and bring her overall medals tally to nine.A delighted Bethany said last night: ldquoThe medals are a personal achievement, whereas the OBE is recognition from others, itrsquos not something I can train for.ldquoTo be honest, I couldnrsquot believe it when I found out. I was overwhelmed. Itrsquos so nice to be acknowledged.This isnrsquot the first time Bethany has been recognised for her achievements, having received an MBE in .ldquoThe MBE was overwhelming in itself, so to be listed for this is a whole dferent experience, she said.The Paralympic swimmer has endured a tough time outside of the pool, having struggled with shoulder injuries before the Games and most recently broken her foot last November.ldquoLast year was a really dficult year. There was a lot of uncertainty around injuries, said Bethany.ldquoI got my cast off just before Christmas and had my foot put in a boot because the doctors werenrsquot happy with how it was healing.ldquoSo now Irsquom in a boot for another six weeks. Itrsquos a hard start to the year, especially with my disability as it is easy to forget and six weeks away is not ideal for me at all. I constantly need repetition in my training.Despite being forced out of the water, Bethany has still managed to engage in some sort of training and noted how much she has learnt in overcoming such adversities.ldquoThe support Irsquove received in training is amazing. I got a swim bench to help my upper body movements and even though I wasnrsquot in the water, I was still in the same environment, she said.ldquoLast year taught me that itrsquos important to have a big goal, but even more so to set little goals just to make sure yoursquore moving.ldquoTherersquos days where I could have stayed in bed and not necessarily needed to train, and these are the ones that count the most.Bethanyrsquos main objective is to be fully fit in time for this summerrsquos Commonwealth Games. She says she will be proud to wear the swim hat of her native Northern Ireland.ldquoI have received so much support from Northern Ireland people as a whole and I canrsquot wait to represent them this year, she said.ldquoOf course I swim for Team GB, but sometimes I think Northern Ireland gets overlooked because of that.ldquoThatrsquos why Irsquom so excited to be representing my country and hopefully I will be able to repay the support I get as I couldnrsquot compete without it..prettyPhoto

title: Support scheme to help small businesses
story: A NEW support programme has been launched for small to medium sized enterprisesand entrepreneurs across the district.Spearheaded by Newry, Mourne and Down Council, the Strategise for Success Programme starts in the New Year and is part of the local authorityrsquos Business Growth programme.The new initiative will provide assistance to participants which need to have a clear and simple plan in place when it comes to growing their business successfully.Council officials say there are many elements surrounding business strategy, but the core fundamentals remain the same, regardless of the industry.They say that understanding these fundamentals is a skill that will aid the development of a successful business plan, with expert mentors helping local businesses focus on understanding what a business strategy is, how useful it is and how to plan their business strategy and practices moving forward.Council chairwoman Cathy Mason said the organisation worked closely with local SMEs on a day-to-day basis.ldquoThe local authority listens to their concerns and needs and has designed specic support programmes to address them. This new programme is an exciting opportunity for businesses from a wide range of sectors and industries as they look towards .ldquoThese programmes may be crucial in helping to retain jobs in our local economy and with a successful business strategy, business owners may even be able to expand and create new jobs.Cllr Mason said it has been an tough time for many of the micro and small businesses based in the district as they continue to face many dficult decisions in an ever-changing and uncertain environment.She added: ldquoI encourage anyone that thinks they may be able to benefit from such support to register as soon as possible.The Strategise for Success Programme involves tailored one-to-one mentoring and targeted online workshops, focusing on business strategy and planning strategies for the future.In addition, support is open to any small business located in the Newry, Down and Down l area with less than  employees and registration is free.Businesses can register for support via the programme by email: curtis@fullcircle.eu, with the deadline for applications pm on Friday, January ..prettyPhoto

title: Trials and tribulations  of preaching in Irish
story: RADEMON Non-Subscribing Presbyterian Church was rebuilt by Dr Moses Neilson in .As well as preaching, Dr Neilson ran a famous school, teaching Classics to prepare students for university entrance in Scotland. He also taught commercial subjects like arithmetic and bookkeeping, for use in commerce and industry.Dr Neilson and his clergymen sons were notable for their warm cross-denominational outlook.Fr Luke Walsh, PP in North Antrim, near Ballycastle, spoke highly of his old Kilmore tutor: ldquoI was educated by a Presbyterian clergyman, a man of as great moral worth and sterling integrity as Ireland could boast of.In , as Bishop of Down and Dromore, William Crolly described Rev James Neilson of Downpatrick as ldquoone of the most liberal and respected clergymen in Co Down.Around  Moses began compiling an Irish grammar, later assisted by his son William. In their pursuit of Irish studies, the two Neilsons collaborated with Patrick Lynch, principal of a distinguished Irish and Classical academy in Loughinisland, six miles away.In March  William Neilson was installed as minister of Dundalk Presbyterian Church. This was a perfect fit for his developing academic interests. Attached to the Dundalk congregation was a colony of Gaelic-speaking Scots Presbyterians living in Ballymascanlon.Originally from Argylle, they had fought for King William in . Hence it was a standing requirement that the congregationrsquos clergy be fluent in Irish.William thrived in Dundalk. In the late s Irish was still the first language with large parts of the population in Down and Louth . He preached widely in Irish. In July  he went on a preaching tour of Ulster, achieving wide popularity.RebellionBack in Co Down, and during the  Rebellion period, his preaching activities on one occasion brought him into collision with the military authorities. His father was actually Moderator in the year of the Rising.Dr Moses needed permission from General Nugent to hold the General Synodin Lurgan that August. One Sunday in  his son William was invited back to his fatherrsquos church, to preach in Irish. The event generated considerable interest, and the church was packed.The authorities were nervous in the wake of the rebellion and news of this unusually large assembly soon reached official ears.Halfway through the sermon a party of yeomen entered the church. With no space left to seat them, they occupied the twin staircases leading up to the pulpit. When William had finished preaching they promptly arrested him, and seized theof his sermon.The soldiers involved were likely from the Kilmore Yeomanry. Their Lieutenant at the time was Charles Hamilton, William Strain of Kilmore was a sergeant, and Patrick Soy of "Tollinagrew" a private.They marched William all the way to Down Gaol in Downpatrick, newly opened on the Mall in  . Their arrival likely caused some consternation with the Gaol Governor, because the Neilson clergy were widely known to be loyal to the Crown.Rev William bailed by Rev JamesScrambling to smooth over this military faux pas, the Governor sent across town for James Neilson, brother of the prisoner, and minister of the nearby Stream Street Presbyterian congregation. The Rev William was then bailed into the custody of the Rev James,with instructions to appear in court next day.Next morning the magistrate encountered a dficulty mdash he couldnrsquot understand the manuscript of Williamrsquos sermon, preached in Irish the day before. William helpfully offered to translate. It transpired the contents were innocuous, and the prisoner was promptly released. The details of this intriguing episode were recorded a century later by a Neilson descendant .Academic careerIn Dundalk William ran a Classical and mercantile academy similar to his fatherrsquos. In an astonishing burst of creativity, he continued to develop his skills as a linguist.In  he published Greek exercises in syntax, ellipsis, dialects, prosody and metaphrasis. In recognition of this, Glasgow University awarded him an honorary DD in . In  he was elected Presbyterian Moderator. In  he published Introduction to the Irish language, on the basis of which he was elected MRIA in .There were a number of advantages in learning Irish, William explained. For academics, it gave essential insights into other European languages. And for the wider population, it enabled competent communication with those large sections of the population whose first language was still Irish.In contemporary Ireland, he asserted, clergymen, lawyers and farmers could not conduct their business properly without a knowledge of Irish.Paradoxically, the subjects taught in schools run by the Neilson clergy, and others, eventually undermined the use of Irish nationally. The Industrial Revolution was in full swing, and employment opportunities in industry and commerce were exploding.For those without a knowledge of English, Irish-only fluency was becoming an overwhelming disadvantage. When the new national school system was instituted in Ireland in , teachers knew that English was now the essential passport to wider employment.The great Daniel OrsquoConnell ruefully acknowledged the new reality. ldquoAlthough the language is associated with many recollections that twine round the hearts of Irishmen, yet the superior utility of the English tongue, as the medium of all modern communication is so great, that I can witness, without a sigh, the gradual disuse of Irish.At that time there were a number of ieties of Irish, but under the new dispensation the vernacular spoken in East Ulster eventually became extinct. Fortunately William Neilson preserved many Co Down examples in his  Grammar. In the words of his descendant Joseph Nelson, Williamrsquos ldquodialogues and familiar phrases, which form the second part, are a complete guide to the ideas as well as the phrases of the peasantry.Untimely deathIn  William was appointed professor of classical languages and Hebrew at the Belfast Academical Institution. In April  he was elected professor of Classics at Glasgow University. However, he had contracted rheumatic fever, and died on the th of that month, aged only . He was buried in the family vault close to the west gable of his fatherrsquos church in Rademon.A full colour pamphlet based on this article has been produced by Rowallane and Slieve Croob Community Group, to accompany Joyce Gibsonrsquos ongoing Irish language classes in Ballynahinch Market House..prettyPhoto

title: Tributes to former chief librarian at Linen Hall Library who was also decorated Gaelic player
story: A LOUGHINISLAND man who was the custodian of some of Northern Irelandrsquos most precious books and written history will be buried tomorrow.The former chief librarian of Belfastrsquos Linen Hall Library, John Killen was hailed as a ldquogentleman and friend to all after he died peacefully at his home on Sunday.A respected author, historian and former Gaelic footballer, Mr Killen was aged .He had worked at Irelandrsquos oldest and last subion library for  years and became friends with some of its most regular visitors, such as the poet Seamus Heaney, writers Sam Hanna Bell, John Hewitt, Joseph Tomelty and the artist Padraic Woods.Mr Killen retired in January , after taking up his first role as an Irish reference librarian at the Linen Hall in .He was known for continuing the work of a former colleague, Jimmy Vitty, by establishing an extensive political papers section of posters, prisonersrsquo books and records from the Maze Long Kesh.The collection houses more than , separate items and is now used by academics and students from across the world.Among the many books written by Mr Killen was the story of the  year-old library, along with the Irish Christmas Book and The Unkindest Cut: A Cartoon History of Ulster -, as well as books on the Irish famine and the United Irishmen.One of his most recent books was The St Patrickrsquos Treasury, a celebration of the myths, legends and traditions of Irelandrsquos patron saint who is buried in the grounds of Down Cathedral.Mr Killen was also highly regarded as a county hurler and Gaelic footballer who won championship medals, having played for his home club Loughinisland, Downpatrickrsquos RGU and Queenrsquos.Loughinisland GAC said on social media the club was ldquodevastated to learn of Mr Killenrsquos death who had also been a member and secretary in .He won two championship medals with the club in  and .Mr Killen, who was reared in Saul, started as a Gaelic footballer with RGU.He won several Minor championships medals for the Downpatrick side, including leading them to victory over Loughinisland in the SFC final in .Queenrsquos GAA remembered on social media how Mr Killen was a former Sigerson Cup player from - and was also part of the first All-Ireland Freshers winning team in .The Linen Hall Library shared its reaction to the sad news on social media.It said of its former head: ldquoJohn joined the Library in  and dedicated the next  years to this institution. Much loved by staff, members, visitors and the world of librarianship at large. A gentleman and friend to all.The news of Mr Killenrsquos passing was also marked by Belfastrsquos Lord Lieutenant, Fionnuala Jay-OrsquoBoyle, CBE, who said on social media: ldquoJohnrsquos contribution to literacy, creativity, history in the city was sustained and distinguished.South Down MP Chris Hazzard paid his condolences to the Killen family and called him ldquoa scholar and a Gael.Former SDLP Leader, Baroness Margaret Ritchie, wrote on social media that Mr Killen was ldquoa lovely, courteous, knowledgeable person on many historical matters.Political commentator Eamonn Mallie praised Mr Killen for his passion and love of books.Mr Killenrsquos funeral will leave his late residence tomorrow for Requiem Mass at am at St Macartanrsquos Church in Loughinisland with internment at the adjoining cemetery afterwards.He is survived by his we Marian, children Emma, Jonathan, Stephen and Orla, grandchildren Eoghan, Anna, Fionn, Catherine, Peter and Eloise, brother Paddy, sister Mary, son-in-law Ruairiacute and daughters-in-law Lenka and Kirsten. He was predeceased by a brother, James..prettyPhoto

title: While I love the sound of Latin I’m not sure I’d be great at it I’m currently doing ballroom and my posture works well with it
story: LOVE Island star Matthew MacNabb said he has no qualms about showing off his chest when he takes part in RTE Onersquos Dancing With The Stars on Sunday evening.The  year-old Downpatrick man will be putting on his dancing shoes to compete with his professional dance partner against  other celebrities and personalities.His time on Dancing With The Stars will be a lot dferent than when he appeared on the hit dating show over the summer.The body builder and fitness fanatic made a real impression on the show, even though he did not make to the final as he failed to stay in a couple.His physique was admired by contestants and viewers and he was loved for his deadpan humour and his speedy dumping of former love interest, Kaz Kamwi.Male celebrities on Dancing With The Stars are usually asked to embrace being sprayed tanned, wearing quite flamboyant costumes and make-up for the show.Matthew admitted: ldquoIrsquove got to be honest, itrsquos an adjustment but I donrsquot really have much shame so Irsquoll go with it and enjoy it. But Irsquom a beach dude at heart so walking about with the top off is my thing.He revealed that while Latin ballroom dance styles excite him, he was learning ballroom first before Christmas.ldquoI have been practicing for about a week now. I practiced all over Christmas. Christmas Eve, Christmas Day, Boxing Day and New Yearrsquos day are my only days Irsquove chosen to take off.ldquoWhile I love the sound of Latin, Irsquom not sure Irsquod be great at it. Irsquom currently doing ballroom and my posture works well with it.He made sure that he keep up his fitness work over the holiday period ahead of the live show.ldquoIrsquom on a mission to get in the best shape possible so I will track my calories over the holidays but will also have fun mdash le is for living.The Russell Gaelic Unionplayer admits that when it comes to dancing, he is a complete novice.ldquoThe only dance experience I have is in nightclubs. My sisters Nadine, Muiread and Conagh were good Irish dancers though.Matthew is the son of local businessman Vincent MacNabb, who runs MacNabbrsquos waste management company, and his we Margaret. He has one older brother Conaill. He admits he did not realise he would end up on a dance show when he was approached about doing Love Island.ldquoI didnrsquot foresee it, no. I just work on my own goals, enjoy my le with a positive attitude and normally God surprises me with new adventures. I never hesitate, no matter how scary. I always say yes.Matthewrsquos le has changed since his Love Island stint but he is embracing it all.ldquoItrsquos been really fun, a serious adjustment but Irsquom still just enjoying the things that make my happy, fitness, travelling, friends and family and now dancing. ldquoWork has been an adjustment too because Im doing content creation pretty much full time and I did digital marketing with MCN Marketing Consultancy but doing it for yourself and understanding the subtle nuances is new.ldquoI signed with as an athlete for one of my favourite brands, MyProtein which was a big dream for me. Use code: Matthew for discount.Catch Matthew on Dancing With The Stars show this Sunday at .pm..prettyPhoto

title: Women are key to the fabric of our society  and the day to day working of our world  – yet face inequalities
story: AN artistrsquos work to promote female equality and ersity across race, religion, sexual orientations is on display at Castlewellan Library until the end of the month.Lise says female equality is a ldquovitally important, core message to be promoting and supporting across our community at a time when there has been an ldquoincredible increase in social depravity, hate crime and domestic violence during the pandemic.She says her art collection and programme ldquoaims to support and promote female equality and ersity across race, religion, sexual orientations.ldquoBy stripping away their dferences, I have instead focused on the complex emotions that are felt by all females. This body of work celebrates the humanism and psychological dexterity of us all, both inidually and as a gender sector.ldquoWorking as an inidual to support equality for both males and females is wonderful.ldquoBut, by working together to achieve it as a society. Then we are invincible and real change can happen.She added: ldquoThis is especially relevant during these unprecedented, pandemic times. Where the glass ceiling still remains almost permanently unbroken.ldquoMore importantly, domestic abuse has increased horrendously, behind shut doors during the  months of lockdown.Newry, Mourne and Down Council chairwoman Cathy Mason is supporting the event.She said: ldquoWomen are key to the fabric of our society and the day to day working of our world. Yet, we still see women disproportionately under-represented in areas such as education employment and leadership. No doubt women are also disproportionately affected by austerity including the cuts to Universal Credit and cuts to public sector jobs.ldquoIt is sad that still today, women continue to face long standing structural inequalities that push more women out of employment and into a state of economic deadlock.Taking a male view point on the subject, Cllr Glyn Hanna said: ldquoI have been involved in politics for years and also have a business. I have seen on many occasions that there remain equality issues for women in work places.ldquoI have three daughters who all have professional jobs. I have been told by them of their experiences of sexual discrimination and inequality and their feelings that they have to work harder to get respect doing a job. More work does need done to address this problem urgently.Agreeing with both councillors, Lise said: ldquoWhat the councillors are saying is so true. So passionate am I to keep female equality high on the public agenda, itrsquos the focus of the creation and touring of this exhibition. It is at the core of my lsquoI Am Womanrsquo Arts and Cultural Programme.She added: ldquoI am focused on promoting all forms of equality and ersity in Northern Ireland.The I Am Woman programme was first launched at Parliament Buildings, Stormont, in September and was attended by MLAs and VIPs.But Lisersquos work is not just focused at reaching the ear of politicians.She said: ldquoMy personal agenda is more about reaching out and spreading the necessity for equality, in all formats. In all walks of our society, from both a ground level up and top down.ldquoI feel that we all have a moral responsibility, when it comes to supporting and promoting female, and other, equality here in Northern Ireland. Forwe donrsquot work together, then nothing changes.ldquoMy programmes are embracing, not preaching. They aim to break down the dferences we have as a society by promoting better knowledge, tolerance and understanding.ldquoThe laws that govern us all, especially those written in relation to females, do definitely need to change for equality to happen.She continued: ldquoWe, as a society, also have to encourage change from the ground level up. Educating our young people and changing adult preconceived perceptions are also so important.ldquoBoys and girls, men and women. We are all iniduals who should be treated fairly and equally. By law, and by society in general.ldquoIt is therefore important to engage and stand up for change now. Otherwise, females will continue to be treated as second class citizens in Northern Ireland, for generations to come.ldquoBoth males and females have so much to give our society. In order for a fairer, more democratic society to exist. Females should always be treated equally at all levels.Lise added: ldquoAfter all, it is women who make up the majority of the adult population in this country.This is Lisersquos third project to be showcased at Parliament Buildings.Any school or business interested in hosted Lisersquos exhibitions and or workshops should email LiseMcGreevyPhotographic@gmail..prettyPhoto

title: the news letter today announces new deputy and political editors
story: DUP stresses ‘£.m’ daily cost of Protocol ahead of crunch meeting   Bryson hits out at stream of ‘fire and fury’ from nationalists over his ‘classic judo move’ anti-Protocol strategyNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsNationalThe News Letter today announces new deputy and political editorsThe News Letter has appointed a new deputy editor and political editor.By Ben LowrySaturday, th January , : amUpdated Saturday, th January , : am  "       "  Roderick McMurray and Henry McDonald will join the paper next month.Roderick, from Dromore Co Down, is a former news editor at this newspaper.He began his career at the Tyrone Courier, then spent  years at the News Letter, rising to news editor, before ing to Tyrone Courier as deputy editor.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.Henry McDonald, an author of nine books who has worked for , The Observer, The Sunday Times, BBC, the Irish News and Sunday News, now becomes deputy editor of the News LetterHenry McDonald, from Belfast, brings a wealth experience to his new role. He has reported during the Troubles, the build up to the ceasefires, and in Easter  wrote one of the definitive accounts of how the Belfast Agreement was secured. He has also written from Lebanon and he reported the first Gulf War. An author of nine books, Henry has worked for , The Observer, The Sunday Times, BBC, the Irish News and Sunday News. Now he has come back home to Northern Ireland to guide readers through the twists and turns of Ulster politics.The News Letter editor Ben Lowry said: “I am delighted to have Rod and Henry joining us. It is a real vote of confidence in the paper that we are recruiting such high calibre journalists, and all the more reason for readers to subscribe!” • To subscribe to the print edition and save % go tolocalsubsplus pg NSLsee page  inside for more information. title: ben lowry tony blair was a flawed prime minister but of course he should be addressed as sir
story: DUP stresses ‘£.m’ daily cost of Protocol ahead of crunch meeting   Bryson hits out at stream of ‘fire and fury’ from nationalists over his ‘classic judo move’ anti-Protocol strategyNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsOpinionBen Lowry: Tony Blair was a flawed prime minister but of course he should be addressed as SirThe furious reaction to Tony Blair getting a knighthood reflects a worrying — and often illogical — public contempt for politicians.By Ben LowrySaturday, th January , : amUpdated Saturday, th January , : pm  "       "  Tony Blair had into adulthood wanted to be a rock star, then he finally got his celebrity moment when hailed by President George W BushWhether or not you like the former prime minister ought to be beside the point.Personally, I am no fan of the ex Labour leader. I do not trust people who are all-things-to-all-men, least of all people who seek high elected office on that basis.There were early warning signs of problems with Mr Blair, not least the way that he projected himself as almost archetypal Tory English, but also in a way Scottish, and then — when he addressed the Dail and talked of Ireland being in his blood — as Irish too.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.I also deeply disliked that ridiculous image of him entering Downing Street with a guitar.This, let us remember, is a man who wanted to be a rock star when he was younger. Not at age  or , but he actually still harboured such ambitions after he left Oxford University.I have a theory that Blair’s undoing is rooted in that specic vanity — the desire to be a rock celebrity. Because he achieved a iation on it in September  , days after the terrorist attacks in America.The then President George W Bush was addressing both houses of Congress in the US, in the fevered aftermath of the atrocities. Tony Blair, who had been the first foreign leader to speak to Mr Bush after the attacks, had flown out to America and was a special guest for the speech.The president turned at one point to the UK prime minister and said that the US needed allies like him.“Thank you, friend,” Mr Bush said.The cameras zoomed in on Mr Blair, who seemed to be suppressing his delight as the parliamentary leaders of America gave him a standing ovation.At that moment, one of the biggest television audiences in America, at a time of national crisis, was cheering the MP for Sedgefield.Think about that.No rock star has ever had a moment like it.Not even the Beatles, who tended to appeal to younger generations, have attracted the adoration of almost an entire superpower.And it was almost asMr Blair, having had the stardom that he had long sought, resolved internally never to put in jeopardy that mass affection.The rest, including his downfall, is history. As it happens I thought he was largely right about that thug Saddam Hussein, evenhe was disastrously wrong in the specics of weapons of mass destruction.I also did not like Blair’s approach to Northern Ireland. While he held firm on important unionist principles in the run-up the Belfast Agreement of , he then initiated an approach to NI politics of appeasement of republicans that has persisted to the present day.But of course he should get a knighthood!Indeed Mr Blair should have been offered it the day he left office.If we are going to be a society that has an honours systems, andthat honours system is going to have a culture known as ‘gong by rank’ , then plainly the head of government should be at the very top of the list.By the way I recall reading many years ago that ‘gong by rank’ would be phased out, and that awards would be based on achievement, not on position. But as far as I can see high court judges still get them automatically.A high court judicial position is one of immense importance and prestige, and such office holders should be worthy of the job and,so, deserving of great respect.But being prime minister is much more important still.It is for that reason that most people can remember and name every prime minister of their letime .Thus even the most short-tenured prime ministers such as Alec Douglas-Home in the s are remembered more than  years later in a way that few other public figures are known.Don’t be fooled by Boris Johnson. For most incumbents, being PM is no fun thing.Indeed perhaps a majority of inhabitants of Downing St in recent decades have emerged as damaged human beings, in some cases almost broken .How absurd that we honour pop stars with knighthoods and people who have achieved great but brief success in, say, athletics but not someone who has been premier of the United Kingdom.What a reflection on our loathing of those who do the vital job of politics.• Ben Lowryis News Letter editor• Ben Lowry: You can already see something of a stretch in the evenings——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: ben lowry you can see something of a stretch in the evenings stretch already

Pic Colm Lenaghan  PacemakerWhere I was based, on the other side of Belfast Lough, the day began with a frost which quickly wore off.For a while I was working in a room into which bright sunshine was streaming.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.There was an uplting sense of an emerging spring.I often write on these pages about the shortening or ening days, and how I find November a month full of gloom and January a month full of optimism, as the light gradually but noticeably begins to .Yet for all my focus on the topic of the seasons and equinoxes and the solstices, even I was struck by an observation of an elderly — now deceased — relative years ago one day in early January . He was hosting family for Sunday lunch and as I gave my spiel about the joys of January and light retuning, he said: yes, you can see the stretch already!Even I, deeply sympathetic to such a perspective, wondered: really  So soon But in fact I have long since realised that he was correct.The earliest sunset of the year is some days before the December  winter solstice, around Dec  to , so the days have by now been stretching for almost a month. The sun sets in Belfast at .pm today, more than  minutes later than that earliest sunset.• Ben Lowryis News Letter editor• Ben Lowry: Tony Blair was a flawed prime minister but of course he should be addressed as Sir——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: owen polley disrespect to unionists belies threadbare new ireland rhetoric
story: Car enthusiasts plan tribute to murder victim Aidan Mann   Bank holidays  Northern Ireland: Full list of bank holidays including Easter and Queens Platinum JubileeNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsOpinionOwen Polley: Disrespect to unionists belies threadbare ‘New Ireland’ rhetoricOver the past few years, we have been asked to believe that a serious discussion is taking place about building a ‘shared’ or ‘new’ Ireland.By Owen PolleySaturday, th January , : amUpdated Saturday, th January , : am  "       "  An MLA asked permission to plant a piece of greenery on the Stormont estate under the royal ‘Green Canopy’ project. Sinn Fein’s Conor Murphy said noSinn Fein, its allies and its proxies have played a prominent role in promoting this way of thinking.They claim that unionists have been invited to join a ‘respectful’ conversation aimed at creating an ‘inclusive’ and ‘progressive’ -county republican state. This language is chosen to appeal to people who see themselves as more reasonable, rational and, let’s face it, superior to those of us who have a fixed preference for remaining in the UK.    " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.But do buzzwords like ‘shared’, ‘respectful’ and ‘inclusive’ really mean anything in the context of Northern Ireland’s proposed destruction  Most of the evidence suggests that they do not and we’ve seen two good examples this week.First, there was the saga of the Queen’s platinum jubilee tree. The DUP MLA, Joanne Bunting, asked for permission to plant this piece of greenery on the Stormont estate, as part of the ‘Green Canopy’ project. This is a royal initiative encouraging people to “plant a tree for the jubilee”, as an environmentally sound way of marking the th anniversary of the Queen taking the throne.Bunting’s proposal should have been uncontroversial but, unfortunately, the finance department has responsibility for the grounds around the Assembly and it is led by Sinn Fein’s Conor Murphy. The request to plant a tree was denied. In an attempt to explain, the minister released a statement. “My department’s policy on commemorative structures or planting on the grounds of the Stormont estate is to approve only those requests which commemorate international events.”If nothing , this explanation was consistent, as it is not the first time Sinn Fein has vetoed horticulture it sees as too unionist friendly. Last year Murphy prevented the planting of a rose bush at Stormont to mark Northern Ireland’s centenary. The party may see everything through the greenest tinted spectacles, but it cannot be accused of being overly green-fingered.On Twitter, a former Fianna Fail candidate, Fintan Cox, described its latest decision as “shockingly petty... bordering on sectarian hatred ... a bloody tree!” There was widespread incredulity on social media that Murphy could block such a harmless gesture.Later in the week, though, Sinn Fein was involved in a similar incident and this time it complained about ... a book! The offending volume, ‘Conspicuous Gallantry’ by Anthony Leask, was visible behind the TUV leader, Jim Allister, during a Stormont committee video meeting.Maoliosa McHugh, one of Sinn Fein’s burgeoning phalanx of unelected MLAs, interrupted the call to ask the Assembly clerk for an investigation into the permissibility of displaying the publication. ‘Conspicuous Gallantry’ records stories from the men and women of the thBattalion of the UDR.Sinn Fein and others have long tried to demonise this regiment, which suffered horric casualties during the Troubles, portraying the crimes of a few rogue soldiers as systemic ‘collusion’ with loyalist paramilitaries.Allister responded, “Having blocked a centenary stone, a rose bush ... and a tree planted for Her Majesty’s jubilee, republicans now ... try to dictate the contents of my study!” McHugh justied his intervention by claiming, “Workplaces should be neutral spaces.” By this logic, anyone who occasionally works from home should conduct an equality audit of their bedrooms or kitchens, before taking their next Zoom call. The imperative to take offence can call for ingenuity at times. A contemptuous attitude to anything associated with unionism, by people who claim they wish to be respectful, is not confined to Sinn Fein. You hear similar things from nearly all the leading voices in the ious campaigns for a ‘shared’ or ‘new’ Ireland. Indeed, it is almost a prerequisite for anyone who pushes this view in the media, or even just on Twitter or podcasts. The implication is that unionists must shape the  county state while they can, because their place in the United Kingdom and their hopes for Northern Ireland’s future are about to be destroyed. These frequent outbursts actually epitomise neatly the latest wave of nationalist campaigning and it is genuinely useful to have such plain-speaking. It’s a necessary counterpoint to meaningless platitudes about sharing and respect. These campaigners are all smiles and kind words while the ‘conversation’ about Northern Ireland’s constitutional position remains entirely on their terms. When unionists articulate alternative ideas about the future or challenge nationalist assumptions, the smiles soon disappear to reveal ugly and laughably premature Irish nationalist triumphalism.So long as we hear plenty of that and Sinn Fein keep making petty decisions, fewer naive people, at least, will be taken in by empty rhetoric about a ‘new Ireland’.——— ———A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: a message from the editor subscribe to save on worlds oldest daily newspaper
story: DUP stresses ‘£.m’ daily cost of Protocol ahead of crunch meeting   Bryson hits out at stream of ‘fire and fury’ from nationalists over his ‘classic judo move’ anti-Protocol strategyNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedEntertainmentTechnologyLestyleHome and GardenFashion and BeautyDealsPuzzlesPublic NoticesFree Happy AdsNewsPeopleA message from the editor: Subscribe to save on world’s oldest daily newspaper!We are now in the year , when theNews Letter will turn .By Ben LowrySaturday, th January , : amUpdated Saturday, th January , : am  "       "  As regular readers know, we are the oldest English language daily newspaper in the world.It’s a record of which we are proud and which we plan never to lose, always, in our grand old age, staying half a century ahead of newcomers like The Times— founded in  compared to our !Look at the montage of front pages on this web page, spanning almost three centuries, to get a glimpse of the range of stories we have reported over that vast time-span.   " fill"#ea"   to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...This site is protected by reCAPTCHA and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.Front pages of the Belfast News Letter over the last  years: From October  the earliest surviving edition of the paper from December  at the height of the Crimean War from September  at the time of the Ulster covenant from September  at the start of World War Two from November  at the assasination of John F Kennedy from April  at the time of the Belfast Agreement and from Jauary  the year the paper will turn You will have noticed that this morning our cover price rose to £. No-one welcomes such an increase, so let me explain it.Producing a newspaper of this size entails immense costs — a bumper Saturday edition of  pages, with  pages of Farming Le. A total of  pages, like a mini book, which tens of thousands of people enjoy across Northern Ireland each weekend.Scores of people, from reporters to accounting staff to printers, are employed to get these newspapers sourced, published and into the shops.Ben Lowry, the editor: "Today alone in the print edition we have  pages of news from our excellent reporters, a weekend section,  pages of sport,  pages of Farmiing Le. Online we update the site daily and subscribers get unlimited access to all columns from the biking star Jonathan Rea to regular favourites Owen Polley, Sandra Chapman, Henry McDonald, Ruth Dudley Edwards, Jonny McCambridge Tim McGarry"That was always an expensive operation, but all the more so in a time of inflation and in particular sharply rising printing costs.You can offset the increase in price by taking a subscription to the News Letter. There are ious digital and print and combined offerings.It is certainly worth it!Today alone we have  pages of news from our excellent reporters. Then churches by Billy Kennedy and columns from Owen Polley on politics, by the barrister Austen Morgan analysing a recent hooded men court ruling, by our regular favourite Sandra Chapman and by the biking star Jonathan Rea.Next week we have columns as usual by Henry McDonald , Ruth Dudley Edwards, Jonny McCambridge and Tim McGarry.Our weekend interview this week is with Victor Chestnutt, president of the Ulster Farmer’s Union, in which he talks about matters ranging from reading his Bible to the Northern Ireland Protocol.We also have another extract from the book ‘The Idea of the Union,’ this time from the historian Brian Barton.Our  pages of sport today includes not just Rea, but lots of coverage of fixtures such as Irish League football.Thank you for staying with us, our faithful readers, and supporting our quality journalism in an age in which news can come from many sources, some unknown and unreliable. • To subscribe to the print edition and save % go to localsubsplus pg NSLsee page  inside for more information. title: ogmore by sea one uks best dog friendly beaches
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe region comes in at fth place with  beaches dogs are able to use  days a year. It comes in behind Pembrokeshire at first place with  beaches, Devon with , Cornwall with  and Anglesey with .The research comes as people are looking to continue to holiday at home as Wales and the UK begins to re-open and international travel is still looking unsure. It was carried out by Uswitch and can be viewed here: https:www.uswitch car-insurance guides uk-dog-friendly-beaches-mapped In their list of  beaches from across the UK, Ogmore Beach comes in third place behind Cayton Bay in North Yorkshire and Oxwich Beach near Swansea.MORE NEWS:Coronavirus: One in three adults in Wales now fully vaccinatedDream seaside home has seven bedrooms and an amazing al-fresco entertaining areaLaurence Llewellyn-Bowen joins campaign to transform oldest Vale homeThe Uswitch guide says that Ogmore Beach is best for fishing, walking and dog-friendly pubs and the car park costs £ a day, with dogs allowed on the beach all-year round and there are no restrictions. They say that the beach is a sand and shingle beach and has a reputation for being one of the cleanest in the region. There is a coastal walk, chance to go fishing, surfing and views of Tusker Rock.For those owners who may not yet have ventured to the beach with their pups or are concerned about behaviour while at the beach, Wood Green’s dog behaviour and training specialist, Wendy Kruger, has provided some tips to prepare your dog for the beach.• Ensure your dog’s microchip and collar tag details are up to date – just in case.• Get used to checking ground surface temperatures before you take your dog out, as dry sand can be too hot for dogs’ paws on sunny days. To check the ground temperature, place the back of your hand on the ground. If its too hot to hold comfortably for five seconds, it’s too hot for dogs’ paws..remove• Practise basic, reward-based training when out and about to help your dog to maintain focus and engagement on walks.• Recall is also an area that needs particular attention. Evenyour dog has a great recall at home, its not something that can be guaranteed in unfamiliar environments with exciting new distractions.
